      <div id="g-story-durban" class="g-story g-hasVideo"
  data-slug="durban">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-durban_39"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/durban-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">7.</span> Durban, South Africa</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">A third city finds its place in the spotlight.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>&#xAD;No one has bad things to say about Durban, per se; they will agree that its beachfront promenade is lovely and the weather is pleasant year round. And yet Durbs, as it is affectionately called, is often scoffed at by Capetonians and Joburgers for being a touch gauche. Well, enough of that. The city&#x2019;s creative set is staking its claim on a hefty share of the country&#x2019;s cool quotient. The reinvention of<a href="https://www.facebook.com/pages/Morrison-Street-Rivertown/1487807424788212"> Rivertown</a> kicked things off: The city enclave is now home to a popular market, beer hall and, coming soon, a raft of boutiques showcasing proudly local brands (<a href="https://www.facebook.com/DirtyIndigo">Dirty Indigo</a> T-shirts;<a href="http://spinebtm.com/"> Spine</a> men&#x2019;s wear). The beloved but dated Durban beachfront is also getting a serious upgrade, courtesy of new dining spots like Afro&#x2019;s Chicken, California Dreaming and Surf Rider&#x2019;s Cafe. Not sure where to start exploring? Order a bunny chow, the quintessential Indian-South African fast food (Durban is home to one of the world&#x2019;s largest Indian communities), and join a city walk led by<a href="http://besetdurban.tumblr.com/"> Beset Durban. </a><span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Sarah Khan</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: School children at uShaka Sea World.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              João Silva/The New York Times
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="durban" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/durban-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=durban" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Durban, South Africa">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Durban, South Africa is No. 7 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/durban-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Durban, South Africa" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Durban, South Africa: A third city finds its place in the spotlight. / #7 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/durban-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Durban, South Africa">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>



      
  
  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825405814183191">Do you know Durban? Tell us what to see.</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825405814183191">On Facebook, a reader said:  “Don't forget about Hluhluwe Imfolozi the oldest and second largest national park in S Africa.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>
  

    </div>
  </div>


  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">7.</span> Durban, South Africa</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"
          itemprop="associatedMedia"
          itemscope=""
          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/durban-900.jpg"

          </figure>
        

      </div> <!-- .g-media -->
    </div> <!-- .g-media-container -->

    
    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">A third city finds its place in the spotlight.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>&#xAD;No one has bad things to say about Durban, per se; they will agree that its beachfront promenade is lovely and the weather is pleasant year round. And yet Durbs, as it is affectionately called, is often scoffed at by Capetonians and Joburgers for being a touch gauche. Well, enough of that. The city&#x2019;s creative set is staking its claim on a hefty share of the country&#x2019;s cool quotient. Order a bunny chow, the quintessential Indian-South African fast food (Durban is home to one of the world&#x2019;s largest Indian communities), and join a city walk led by<a href="http://besetdurban.tumblr.com/"> Beset Durban. </a><span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Sarah Khan</span></p>
        
<ul class="g-related">
  <li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/travel/guides/africa/south-africa/overview.html"><span>Related:</span> Recent South Africa Coverage
</a></li>
</ul>


        

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="durban" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/durban-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=durban" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Durban, South Africa">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Durban, South Africa is No. 7 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/durban-900.jpg">

    </li>

      <div id="g-story-bolivia" class="g-story "
  data-slug="bolivia">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-bolivia_44"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/bolivia-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">8.</span> Bolivia</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">Finally stable and opening up to the world.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>&#xAD;Bolivia&#x2019;s days of relentless transportation strikes and roadblocks are mostly behind it. And travelers who try out the now tourism-friendly infrastructure will be rewarded with new attractions once they arrive. Claus Meyer&#x2019;s two-year-old fine-dining restaurant,<a href="http://restaurantgustu.com/"> Gustu,</a> and<a href="http://meltingpot-bolivia.org/"> the Melting Pot Foundation</a> are helping set a new culinary tone around the country by starting<a href="http://sumaphayata.org/"> Suma Phayata</a>, an official street food tour in La Paz, and renewing interest in high-altitude wine routes in the Tarija region. Adventure excursions also abound, from luxe tent camp trips led by the<a href="http://www.explora.com/explora-uyuni"> Chilean operator Explora</a> across the Salar de Uyuni, the world&#x2019;s largest salt flats, to community tourism projects on<a href="http://www.apasionadocoffee.com/"> coffee farms</a> in the Yungas region, where a new road to Caranavi, expected to open this year will cut the travel time drastically from La Paz. <span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Nicholas Gill</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: Lake Titicaca, with the Andes in the background. </span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Nicholas Gill
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="bolivia" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/bolivia-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=bolivia" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Bolivia">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Bolivia is No. 8 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/bolivia-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Bolivia" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Bolivia: Finally stable and opening up to the world. / #8 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/bolivia-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Bolivia">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>

  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">8.</span> Bolivia</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure

          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>

    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">Finally stable and opening up to the world.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>&#xAD;Bolivia&#x2019;s days of relentless transportation strikes and roadblocks are mostly behind it. And travelers who try out the now tourism-friendly infrastructure will be rewarded with new attractions once they arrive. Claus Meyer&#x2019;s two-year-old fine-dining restaurant,<a href="http://restaurantgustu.com/"> Gustu,</a> and<a href="http://meltingpot-bolivia.org/"> the Melting Pot Foundation</a> are helping set a new culinary tone around the country by starting<a href="http://sumaphayata.org/"> Suma Phayata</a>, an official street food tour in La Paz, and renewing interest in high-altitude wine routes in the Tarija region. Adventure excursions also abound, from luxe tent camp trips led by the<a href="http://www.explora.com/explora-uyuni"> Chilean operator Explora</a> across the Salar de Uyuni, the world&#x2019;s largest salt flats, to community tourism projects on<a href="http://www.apasionadocoffee.com/"> coffee farms</a> in the Yungas region, where a new road to Caranavi, expected to open this year will cut the travel time drastically from La Paz. <span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Nicholas Gill</span></p>

      <div id="g-story-faroe" class="g-story "
  data-slug="faroe">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-faroe_49"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/faroe-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">9.</span> Faroe Islands</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">A remote location is home to the New, New, New Nordic cuisine.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>The Faroe Islands, an archipelago in the North Atlantic, has emerged in the last five years as possibly the most secluded destination for avant-garde food. Leading the way is<a href="http://www.koks.fo/EN/"> Koks</a>, a signatory of the<a href="http://newnordicfood.org/about-nnf-ii/new-nordic-kitchen-manifesto/"> New Nordic Kitchen Manifesto</a>, which stresses modern cuisine made from local, seasonal ingredients, and Aarstova, a French restaurant using Faroese ingredients. In 2015 Aarstova&#x2019;s new fish house, Barbara, will serve the only yearly harvest of the incomparable Faroe Bank cod. There&#x2019;s also innovative sushi at<a href="http://www.etika.fo/"> Etika</a>, and a well-regarded brewery <a href="http://www.okkara.fo/"> Okkara</a>. In addition, the islands are drawing food enthusiasts for their local cheeses and raest, a fermented mutton dish that is a local delicacy. Though isolated, the Faroe Islands &#x2014; an autonomous part of Denmark &#x2014; are a short flight from Copenhagen and Reykjavik.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">David Shaftel</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: Lobster at Koks restaurant in Torshavn.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Benjamin Rasmussen
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="faroe" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/faroe-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=faroe" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Faroe Islands">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Faroe Islands is No. 9 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/faroe-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Faroe Islands" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Faroe Islands: A remote location is home to the New, New, New Nordic cuisine. / #9 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/faroe-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Faroe Islands">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>



      
  
  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825428744180898">Do you know the Faroe Islands? Tell us what to see. </a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825428744180898">On Facebook, a reader said:  “I would recommend climbing to the top of Slættaratindur, the highest mountain in the Faroe Islands.”  <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>
  

    </div>
  </div>


  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">9.</span> Faroe Islands</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"
          itemprop="associatedMedia"
          itemscope=""
          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/faroe-900.jpg"

          aria-label="media"
          role="group">
          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
          <noscript>
            <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/faroe-900.jpg" alt="Photo of Faroe Islands">

          <img

        <!-- Video -->

    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">A remote location is home to the New, New, New Nordic cuisine.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>The Faroe Islands, an archipelago in the North Atlantic, has emerged in the last five years as possibly the most secluded destination for avant-garde food. Leading the way is<a href="http://www.koks.fo/EN/"> Koks</a>, a signatory of the<a href="http://newnordicfood.org/about-nnf-ii/new-nordic-kitchen-manifesto/"> New Nordic Kitchen Manifesto</a>, which stresses modern cuisine made from local, seasonal ingredients, and Aarstova, a French restaurant using Faroese ingredients. In 2015 Aarstova&#x2019;s new fish house, Barbara, will serve the only yearly harvest of the incomparable Faroe Bank cod. There&#x2019;s also innovative sushi at<a href="http://www.etika.fo/"> Etika</a>, and a well-regarded brewery <a href="http://www.okkara.fo/"> Okkara</a>. In addition, the islands are drawing food enthusiasts for their local cheeses and raest, a fermented mutton dish that is a local delicacy. Though isolated, the Faroe Islands &#x2014; an autonomous part of Denmark &#x2014; are a short flight from Copenhagen and Reykjavik.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">David Shaftel</span></p>
        

        

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="faroe" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/faroe-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=faroe" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Faroe Islands">

      <div class="g-tools">
        <div class="g-map"><img 
id="g-map-faroe_52"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-map"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-src="http://int.nyt.com/newsgraphics/2014/20140216-places-to-go/v21_r9/faroe_thumb.png"
data-src-retina="http://int.nyt.com/newsgraphics/2014/20140216-places-to-go/v21_r9/faroe_thumb_2x.png"
></div>
      </div> <!-- .g-tools -->
    </div> <!-- .g-content-container -->


    
  
  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825428744180898">Do you know the Faroe Islands? Tell us what to see. </a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825428744180898">On Facebook, a reader said:  “I would recommend climbing to the top of Slættaratindur, the highest mountain in the Faroe Islands.”  <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>
  


  </div> <!-- .g-view-expanded -->

  

</div> <!-- .g-story -->

    
      <div id="g-story-macedonia" class="g-story "
  data-slug="macedonia">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-macedonia_54"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/macedonia-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">10.</span> Macedonia</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">The next Balkan destination.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>&#xAD;First came Croatia, then Montenegro &#x2014; even Albania is gaining traction on the western Balkan travel circuit. Macedonia is next. Known for its moody monasteries and sparkling Lake Ohrid, this former Yugoslav republic is making a play for adventure foodies, too. It makes sense. Places like the Shar Mountains abound in Alp-like hiking while Macedonia&#x2019;s wine industry &#x2014; once responsible for the bulk of Yugoslavia&#x2019;s supply &#x2014; is enjoying a rebound with local producers. Scores of smaller hotels serving traditional soups and pastries like pastrmajlija, a meat pie, have opened to replace cold socialist haunts. Old establishments like the<a href="http://www.montanapalace.com/"> Hotel Montana Palace</a> in cheese-friendly Krusevo offer newly renovated settings at low Balkan prices. And Macedonia is one of the few places without a McDonald&#x2019;s &#x2014; they all closed in 2013.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Tim Neville</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: Skopje, the capital of Macedonia.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Jodi Hilton
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="macedonia" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/macedonia-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=macedonia" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Macedonia">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Macedonia is No. 10 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/macedonia-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Macedonia" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Macedonia: The next Balkan destination. / #10 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/macedonia-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Macedonia">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>



      
  
  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825427444181028">What are your favorite things to do in Macedonia?</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825427444181028">On Facebook, a reader said:  “One should visit the ancient observatory near Kokino... as well as the ancient pagan temple now called Cocev Kamen near Kratovo.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>
  

    </div>
  </div>


  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">10.</span> Macedonia</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"

          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/macedonia-900.jpg"
          itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"
          aria-label="media"
          role="group">
          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
          <noscript>
            <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/macedonia-900.jpg" alt="Photo of Macedonia">
          </noscript>
          <img

      </div> <!-- .g-media -->

    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">The next Balkan destination.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>&#xAD;First came Croatia, then Montenegro &#x2014; even Albania is gaining traction on the western Balkan travel circuit. Macedonia is next. Known for its moody monasteries and sparkling Lake Ohrid, this former Yugoslav republic is making a play for adventure foodies, too. It makes sense. Places like the Shar Mountains abound in Alp-like hiking while Macedonia&#x2019;s wine industry &#x2014; once responsible for the bulk of Yugoslavia&#x2019;s supply &#x2014; is enjoying a rebound with local producers. Scores of smaller hotels serving traditional soups and pastries like pastrmajlija, a meat pie, have opened to replace cold socialist haunts. Old establishments like the<a href="http://www.montanapalace.com/"> Hotel Montana Palace</a> in cheese-friendly Krusevo offer newly renovated settings at low Balkan prices. And Macedonia is one of the few places without a McDonald&#x2019;s &#x2014; they all closed in 2013.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Tim Neville</span></p>

      <div id="g-story-medellin" class="g-story g-hasVideo"
  data-slug="medellin">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-medellin_59"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/medellin-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">11.</span> Medellín, Colombia</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">Urban renewal with innovative architecture and design.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>&#xAD;Medell&#xED;n&#x2019;s been getting a lot of attention lately for its spectacular urban renewal efforts. Many of the once legendary slums have been transformed through some astonishing architectural gems, like the Biblioteca Espa&#xF1;a, a hyper-modern public library and community space in the low-income Santo Domingo neighborhood. The city&#x2019;s<a href="https://www.metrodemedellin.gov.co/index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=article&amp;id=61&amp;Itemid=165&amp;lang=en"> Metrocables</a> (aerial gondolas) and 1,300 feet of outdoor escalators, developed to integrate the poorer hillside neighborhoods with the city center, are global milestones in smart public transit. New schools and parks dot the city. And an ambitious contemporary expansion to the<a href="http://www.elmamm.org/"> Museo de Arte Moderno</a>, housed in a former steel mill in the up-and-coming Ciudad del Rio neighborhood, is scheduled for completion this year.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Nell McShane Wulfhart</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: An aerial gondola rises above the Santo Domingo neighborhood.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Paul Smith for The New York Times
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="medellin" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/medellin-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=medellin" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Medellín, Colombia">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Medellín, Colombia is No. 11 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/medellin-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Medellín, Colombia" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Medellín, Colombia: Urban renewal with innovative architecture and design. / #11 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/medellin-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Medellín, Colombia">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>



      
  
  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825432854180487">Do know Medellín? Tell us what to see.</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825432854180487">On Facebook, a reader said:  “You have to visit Medellín during La Feria de Las Flores, definitely one of Colombia's more spectacular festivals.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>
  

    </div>

    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">11.</span> Medellín, Colombia</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">Urban renewal with innovative architecture and design.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>&#xAD;Medell&#xED;n&#x2019;s been getting a lot of attention lately for its spectacular urban renewal efforts. Many of the once legendary slums have been transformed through some astonishing architectural gems, like the Biblioteca Espa&#xF1;a, a hyper-modern public library and community space in the low-income Santo Domingo neighborhood. The city&#x2019;s<a href="https://www.metrodemedellin.gov.co/index.php?option=com_content&amp;view=article&amp;id=61&amp;Itemid=165&amp;lang=en"> Metrocables</a> (aerial gondolas) and 1,300 feet of outdoor escalators, developed to integrate the poorer hillside neighborhoods with the city center, are global milestones in smart public transit. New schools and parks dot the city. And an ambitious contemporary expansion to the<a href="http://www.elmamm.org/"> Museo de Arte Moderno</a>, housed in a former steel mill in the up-and-coming Ciudad del Rio neighborhood, is scheduled for completion this year.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Nell McShane Wulfhart</span></p>

      <div id="g-story-stvincent" class="g-story "
  data-slug="stvincent">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-stvincent_64"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/stvincent-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">12.</span> St. Vincent and the Grenadines</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">A new airport and dive center await.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>&#xAD;The largest development project ever undertaken in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, the new $240 million Argyle International Airport will open this year, offering nonstop jet service from North America and Europe to the 32-island nation dotting the Lesser Antilles between St. Lucia and Grenada. Travelers traditionally come to scuba dive or snorkel the island chain&#x2019;s reefs, and the private island resort of<a href="http://www.petitstvincent.com/"> Petit St. Vincent</a> just added a new dive center run by the marine conservationist Jean-Michel Cousteau, with plans to lobby for a marine preserve nearby. <a href="http://www.palmislandresortgrenadines.com/index.htm"> Palm Island Resort</a> manages to preserve the peace for which travelers come and serve social needs with a new weekly Silent Cinema night on the beach (guests watch a movie projected on a big screen while listening via wireless headphones) and a Silent Disco dance party held monthly on the shore.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Elaine Glusac</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: Coral reefs near Petit St. Vincent.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Richard Murphy
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="stvincent" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/stvincent-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=stvincent" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: St. Vincent and the Grenadines">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? St. Vincent and the Grenadines is No. 12 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/stvincent-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>

    </li>

    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825411337515972">What are your favorite things to do in St. Vincent and the Grenadines?</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825411337515972">On Facebook, a reader said:  “And sail to Tobago Cays on the Scaramouche, a wonderful old sailboat with local crew who fix an excellent Caribbean chicken and rice lunch and potent rum punches.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>
  

    </div>
  </div>


  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">12.</span> St. Vincent and the Grenadines</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"
          itemprop="associatedMedia"
          itemscope=""
          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/stvincent-900.jpg"
          itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"
          aria-label="media"
          role="group">
          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
          <noscript>
            <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/stvincent-900.jpg" alt="Photo of St. Vincent and the Grenadines">
          </noscript>
          <img 
id="g-media-stvincent_63"

              </span>
          </figcaption>
        </figure>

        <!-- Video -->
        

      </div> <!-- .g-media -->
    </div> <!-- .g-media-container -->

    
    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">A new airport and dive center await.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>&#xAD;The largest development project ever undertaken in St. Vincent and the Grenadines, the new $240 million Argyle International Airport will open this year, offering nonstop jet service from North America and Europe to the 32-island nation dotting the Lesser Antilles between St. Lucia and Grenada. Travelers traditionally come to scuba dive or snorkel the island chain&#x2019;s reefs, and the private island resort of<a href="http://www.petitstvincent.com/"> Petit St. Vincent</a> just added a new dive center run by the marine conservationist Jean-Michel Cousteau, with plans to lobby for a marine preserve nearby. <a href="http://www.palmislandresortgrenadines.com/index.htm"> Palm Island Resort</a> manages to preserve the peace for which travelers come and serve social needs with a new weekly Silent Cinema night on the beach (guests watch a movie projected on a big screen while listening via wireless headphones) and a Silent Disco dance party held monthly on the shore.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Elaine Glusac</span></p>

      <div id="g-story-orlando" class="g-story "
  data-slug="orlando">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-orlando_69"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/orlando-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">13.</span> Orlando, Florida</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">Beyond Mickey Mouse: a Disney destination matures.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>Disney World will no doubt remain the biggest draw to Orlando, but the city is growing up thanks to a string of civic developments, including the $429 million<a href="http://www.drphillipscenter.org"> Dr. Phillips Performing Arts Center,</a> the 62-mile-long<a href="http://sunrail.com/"> SunRail</a> commuter train, both opened last year, and a coming 19,500-seat soccer stadium set to open this year. But the most surprising development is the food scene.<a href="https://www.eastendmkt.com"> East End Market</a>, and its stalls selling locavore fare and artisanal baked goods, opened in 2013. Last year saw the opening of<a href="http://txokoskitchen.com"> Txokos Basque Kitchen</a>, whose chef was nominated for a James Beard Award. Not to be outdone, two fellow Beard nominees, James and Julie Petrakis (<a href="http://www.theravenouspig.com">The Ravenous Pig</a>,<a href="http://www.caskandlarder.com"> Cask &amp; Larder</a>), announced the February opening of<a href="http://www.swineandsons.com"> Swine &amp; Sons Provisions</a>, their market/restaurant hybrid. Theme parks are expanding adult options as well: the elegant<a href="http://www.fourseasons.com/orlando/"> Four Seasons Resort Orlando at Walt Disney World</a> opened in August 2014 and features a golf course, a rooftop lounge and an adults-only pool.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Adam H. Graham</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: A pork porterhouse at the Ravenous Pig restaurant. </span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Jon Whittle
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="orlando" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/orlando-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=orlando" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Orlando, Florida">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Orlando, Florida is No. 13 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/orlando-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Orlando, Florida" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Orlando, Florida: Beyond Mickey Mouse: a Disney destination matures. / #13 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/orlando-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Orlando, Florida">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>

  </div>

  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">13.</span> Orlando, Florida</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"
          itemprop="associatedMedia"
          itemscope=""
          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/orlando-900.jpg"

          </figcaption>

        <!-- Video -->
        

      </div> <!-- .g-media -->
    </div> <!-- .g-media-container -->

    
    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">Beyond Mickey Mouse: a Disney destination matures.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>Disney World will no doubt remain the biggest draw to Orlando, but the city is growing up thanks to a string of civic developments, including the $429 million<a href="http://www.drphillipscenter.org"> Dr. Phillips Performing Arts Center,</a> the 62-mile-long<a href="http://sunrail.com/"> SunRail</a> commuter train, both opened last year, and a coming 19,500-seat soccer stadium set to open this year. But the most surprising development is the food scene.<a href="https://www.eastendmkt.com"> East End Market</a>, and its stalls selling locavore fare and artisanal baked goods, opened in 2013. Last year saw the opening of<a href="http://txokoskitchen.com"> Txokos Basque Kitchen</a>, whose chef was nominated for a James Beard Award. Not to be outdone, two fellow Beard nominees, James and Julie Petrakis (<a href="http://www.theravenouspig.com">The Ravenous Pig</a>,<a href="http://www.caskandlarder.com"> Cask &amp; Larder</a>), announced the February opening of<a href="http://www.swineandsons.com"> Swine &amp; Sons Provisions</a>, their market/restaurant hybrid. Theme parks are expanding adult options as well: the elegant<a href="http://www.fourseasons.com/orlando/"> Four Seasons Resort Orlando at Walt Disney World</a> opened in August 2014 and features a golf course, a rooftop lounge and an adults-only pool.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Adam H. Graham</span></p>

  <li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/travel/guides/north-america/united-states/florida/overview.html"><span>Related:</span> Recent Florida Coverage</a></li>

      <div id="g-story-zimbabwe" class="g-story "
  data-slug="zimbabwe">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-zimbabwe_74"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/zimbabwe-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">14.</span> Zimbabwe</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">Once-avoided, now must-visit.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>This country&#x2019;s beauty and bounty have been overshadowed by political unrest and economic collapse over the last few decades, but today, the government is finally stable, the overinflated Zimbabwean dollar is gone, and the prices are low. An international terminal at Victoria Falls Airport set to open in July will make it far easier to get to, and new trips from outfitters like<a href="http://www.redsavannah.com/"> Red Savannah</a> and <a href="http://www.coxandkingsusa.com/">Cox and Kings</a> give travelers a way to explore the many riches: There&#x2019;s the spectacular Victoria Falls, the Zambezi, Unesco World Heritage sites like the granite landform Matobo Hills and the colonial charm of cities like Harare. The biggest draw, however, might be the abundance of game, including hippos and lions, on full view on water safaris, like those offered by the new luxury cruiser<a href="http://www.mv-matusadona.com/"> Matusadona, </a>or the old-fashioned way, by land, at upscale lodges like <a href="http://www.imvelosafarilodges.com/bomani-lodge.html"> Bomani Tented Lodge</a> in Hwange National Park.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Shivani Vora</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: The Bomani Tented Lodge in Hwange National Park.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Gemma Catlin
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="zimbabwe" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/zimbabwe-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=zimbabwe" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Zimbabwe">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Zimbabwe is No. 14 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/zimbabwe-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Zimbabwe" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Zimbabwe: Once-avoided, now must-visit. / #14 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/zimbabwe-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Zimbabwe">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>



      
  
  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825433557513750">What did we miss in Zimbabwe? Tell us what to see. </a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825433557513750">On Facebook, a reader said:  “Riding the overnight train from Vic Falls to the easy going pace of life in the country's second city, Bulawayo.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>
  

    </div>
  </div>


  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">14.</span> Zimbabwe</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"
          itemprop="associatedMedia"
          itemscope=""
          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/zimbabwe-900.jpg"
          itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"
          aria-label="media"
          role="group">
          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
          <noscript>
            <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/zimbabwe-900.jpg" alt="Photo of Zimbabwe">
          </noscript>
          <img 
id="g-media-zimbabwe_73"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/zimbabwe-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 640, 720, 900, 1254, 1600, 2200, 2600]"
>
          <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
              <span class="g-caption-text">The Bomani Tented Lodge in Hwange National Park.</span>
              <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
                  <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
                  Gemma Catlin
              </span>
          </figcaption>
        </figure>

        <!-- Video -->
        

      </div> <!-- .g-media -->
    </div> <!-- .g-media-container -->

    
    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">Once-avoided, now must-visit.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>This country&#x2019;s beauty and bounty have been overshadowed by political unrest and economic collapse over the last few decades, but today, the government is finally stable, the overinflated Zimbabwean dollar is gone, and the prices are low. An international terminal at Victoria Falls Airport set to open in July will make it far easier to get to, and new trips from outfitters like<a href="http://www.redsavannah.com/"> Red Savannah</a> and <a href="http://www.coxandkingsusa.com/">Cox and Kings</a> give travelers a way to explore the many riches: There&#x2019;s the spectacular Victoria Falls, the Zambezi, Unesco World Heritage sites like the granite landform Matobo Hills and the colonial charm of cities like Harare. The biggest draw, however, might be the abundance of game, including hippos and lions, on full view on water safaris, like those offered by the new luxury cruiser<a href="http://www.mv-matusadona.com/"> Matusadona, </a>or the old-fashioned way, by land, at upscale lodges like <a href="http://www.imvelosafarilodges.com/bomani-lodge.html"> Bomani Tented Lodge</a> in Hwange National Park.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Shivani Vora</span></p>
        
<ul class="g-related">
  <li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/travel/guides/africa/overview.html"><span>Related:</span> Recent Africa Coverage</a></li>
</ul>


        

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="zimbabwe" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/zimbabwe-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=zimbabwe" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Zimbabwe">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Zimbabwe is No. 14 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/zimbabwe-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Zimbabwe" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>

      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Zimbabwe">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>



      </div>

      <div id="g-story-burgundy" class="g-story "
  data-slug="burgundy">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-burgundy_79"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/burgundy-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">15.</span> Burgundy, France</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">A Unesco candidate gets a redux and a renewed vigor.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>Adieu Burgundy. Bonjour Bourgogne! The renowned wine region has ditched its musty Anglo moniker and reclaimed its French name in all official wine communications. With this rebrand come several changes and a new generation of winemakers and hoteliers. In 2014, the luxury conglomerate LVMH bought the Grand-Cru estate of<a href="http://www.lambrays.com"> Clos Des Lambrays</a> near the village of Morey-St.-Denis, marking their entree to a region peppered with excellent vineyards. The picturesque hub of Beaune continues to draw interest with annual projects like<a href="http://www.etclondonparis.com/en/projects/architectural-projection/lumiere-beaune"> Lumi&#xE8;res de Beaune</a>, light installations on the village&#x2019;s half-timbered houses. Not to be outshone, Dijon is debuting a pair of projects this year: the new<a href="http://www.vertigohoteldijon.com"> Vertigo</a>, a Design Hotel opening in January; and a new beach on Lake Kir that&#x2019;s made with 350 tons of imported sand. Bourgogne has also been nominated for Unesco&#x2019;s 2015 World Heritage list, specifically for its 100 historic appellations that have deepened the collective understanding of the concept of terroir.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Adam H. Graham</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: The Clos Des Lambrays vineyard.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              M. Jean-Louis Bernuy
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="burgundy" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/burgundy-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=burgundy" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Burgundy, France">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Burgundy, France is No. 15 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/burgundy-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Burgundy, France" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Burgundy, France: A Unesco candidate gets a redux and a renewed vigor. / #15 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/burgundy-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Burgundy, France">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>



      
  
  <div class="g-facebookthread">

      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825426620847777">What are your favorite things to do in Burgundy?</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825426620847777">On Facebook, a reader said:  “Near Chablis, visit the very special medieval village Noyers Sur Serein for its architecture, lively and laid-back lifestyle and music.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>

  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">15.</span> Burgundy, France</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->

          aria-label="media"
          role="group">
          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>

    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">A Unesco candidate gets a redux and a renewed vigor.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>Adieu Burgundy. Bonjour Bourgogne! The renowned wine region has ditched its musty Anglo moniker and reclaimed its French name in all official wine communications. With this rebrand come several changes and a new generation of winemakers and hoteliers. In 2014, the luxury conglomerate LVMH bought the Grand-Cru estate of<a href="http://www.lambrays.com"> Clos Des Lambrays</a> near the village of Morey-St.-Denis, marking their entree to a region peppered with excellent vineyards. The picturesque hub of Beaune continues to draw interest with annual projects like<a href="http://www.etclondonparis.com/en/projects/architectural-projection/lumiere-beaune"> Lumi&#xE8;res de Beaune</a>, light installations on the village&#x2019;s half-timbered houses. Not to be outshone, Dijon is debuting a pair of projects this year: the new<a href="http://www.vertigohoteldijon.com"> Vertigo</a>, a Design Hotel opening in January; and a new beach on Lake Kir that&#x2019;s made with 350 tons of imported sand. Bourgogne has also been nominated for Unesco&#x2019;s 2015 World Heritage list, specifically for its 100 historic appellations that have deepened the collective understanding of the concept of terroir.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Adam H. Graham</span></p>

      <div id="g-story-manhattan" class="g-story g-hasVideo"
  data-slug="manhattan">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-manhattan_84"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/manhattan-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">16.</span> Lower Manhattan, New York</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">Ground Zero is in the midst of a remarkable comeback.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>&#xAD;More than a decade after 9/11, the southern tip of Manhattan is becoming one of New York City&#x2019;s most vibrant neighborhoods. The long-awaited<a href="http://www.wtc.com/about/freedom-tower"> One World Trade Center</a> and<a href="http://www.911memorial.org/"> 9/11 Memorial</a>, which opened last year, will soon be surrounded by an appealing array of dining, shopping and lodging establishments. A stunning transportation hub designed by Santiago Calatrava will join the <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/10/nyregion/fulton-center-a-subway-complex-reopens-in-lower-manhattan.html">Fulton Center</a> and its dazzling oculus.<a href="http://www.eataly.com/"> Eataly</a>, Mario Batali&#x2019;s ultra-popular food hall, will soon have a sister location downtown.<a href="http://brookfieldplaceny.com/"> Brookfield Place</a> (formerly known as the World Financial Center) is completing major renovations to make way for over a dozen upscale boutiques, a second food market, and a restaurant by the celebrity chef Jo&#xEB;l Robuchon. The new<a href="http://www.piera.com/about"> Pier A Harbor House</a> offers fresh seafood, craft beers and hard-to-beat harbor views. Also underway: a series of luxurious condominiums and lodgings, including<a href="http://thebeekman.com/"> the Beekman Hotel</a>, set in a turreted 19th-century building with ornate interiors.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Paola Singer</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: Brookfield Place.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Damon Winter/The New York Times
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="manhattan" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/manhattan-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=manhattan" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Lower Manhattan, New York">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Lower Manhattan, New York is No. 16 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/manhattan-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Lower Manhattan, New York" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Lower Manhattan, New York: Ground Zero is in the midst of a remarkable comeback. / #16 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/manhattan-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Lower Manhattan, New York">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>



      
  
  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825426887514417">What do you love to do in Lower Manhattan?</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825426887514417">On Facebook, a reader said:  “Great free noon concerts nearly weekday in Trinity Church.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>
  

    </div>
  </div>


  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">16.</span> Lower Manhattan, New York</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"
          itemprop="associatedMedia"
          itemscope=""
          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/manhattan-900.jpg"
          itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"
          aria-label="media"
          role="group">
          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
          <noscript>
            <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/manhattan-900.jpg" alt="Photo of Lower Manhattan, New York">
          </noscript>
          <img 
id="g-media-manhattan_83"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/manhattan-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 640, 720, 900, 1254, 1600, 2200, 2600]"
>
          <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
              <span class="g-caption-text">Brookfield Place.</span>
              <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
                  <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
                  Damon Winter/The New York Times
              </span>
          </figcaption>
        </figure>

        <!-- Video -->
        
          <figure
            class="g-figure-video"
            itemprop="associatedMedia"
            itemscope=""
            itemid=""
            itemtype="http://schema.org/VideoObject"
            aria-label="media"
            role="group">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Video Player</span>
            <noscript>
              <video autoplay="" loop="" muted="" preload="none" poster="">
                  <source id="mp4" src="" type="video/mp4">
                  <img src="">
              </video>
            </noscript>
            <!-- laziestloader container -->
<div 
id="g-media-manhattan_86"
data-ratio="0.66666667"
data-slug="manhattan"
class="g-lazy-video g-lazy-media">
  <!-- vhs container -->
  <div id="g-media-manhattan_86_vhs" class="g-vhs"></div>
</div>

            <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="g-caption-text">Brookfield Place.</span>
                <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
                    <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
                    Damon Winter/The New York Times
                </span>
            </figcaption>
          </figure>
        

      </div> <!-- .g-media -->
    </div> <!-- .g-media-container -->

    
    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">Ground Zero is in the midst of a remarkable comeback.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>&#xAD;More than a decade after 9/11, the southern tip of Manhattan is becoming one of New York City&#x2019;s most vibrant neighborhoods. The long-awaited<a href="http://www.wtc.com/about/freedom-tower"> One World Trade Center</a> and<a href="http://www.911memorial.org/"> 9/11 Memorial</a>, which opened last year, will soon be surrounded by an appealing array of dining, shopping and lodging establishments. A stunning transportation hub designed by Santiago Calatrava will join the <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/10/nyregion/fulton-center-a-subway-complex-reopens-in-lower-manhattan.html">Fulton Center</a> and its dazzling oculus.<a href="http://www.eataly.com/"> Eataly</a>, Mario Batali&#x2019;s ultra-popular food hall, will soon have a sister location downtown.<a href="http://brookfieldplaceny.com/"> Brookfield Place</a> (formerly known as the World Financial Center) is completing major renovations to make way for over a dozen upscale boutiques, a second food market, and a restaurant by the celebrity chef Jo&#xEB;l Robuchon. The new<a href="http://www.piera.com/about"> Pier A Harbor House</a> offers fresh seafood, craft beers and hard-to-beat harbor views. Also underway: a series of luxurious condominiums and lodgings, including<a href="http://thebeekman.com/"> the Beekman Hotel</a>, set in a turreted 19th-century building with ornate interiors.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Paola Singer</span></p>
        
<ul class="g-related">
  <li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/04/05/travel/new-neighbors-revitalize-battery-park-city.html"><span>Related:</span> "New Neighbors Revitalize Battery Park City"</a></li>
</ul>


        

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="manhattan" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/manhattan-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=manhattan" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Lower Manhattan, New York">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Lower Manhattan, New York is No. 16 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/manhattan-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Lower Manhattan, New York" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>

      <div id="g-story-tanzania" class="g-story "
  data-slug="tanzania">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-tanzania_89"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/tanzania-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">17.</span> Tanzania</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">A safari revival in troubled times.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>Security fears in neighboring Kenya have inadvertently worked in Tanzania&#x2019;s favor, as far as tourism goes: Its luxurious new lodges are enticing diverted visitors. The ever-popular Serengeti retains its cachet with high-profile openings. <a href="http://asiliaafrica.com/">Asilia Africa</a>&#x2019;s secluded Namiri Plains property and roving mobile camp Kimondo opened in July, followed by <a href="http://www.legendaryexpeditions.com">Legendary Expeditions</a>&#x2019; Mwiba Tented Camp in August, and a revamp of <a href="http://andbeyond.com">&amp;Beyond Grumeti</a> Tented Camp is slated to be unveiled this April. But the real new treasure here is unprecedented access to sparsely trafficked regions. <a href="http://nomad-tanzania.com/">Nomad Tanzania</a> opened Kuro amid the baobab-studded landscapes of Tarangire; Azura opened a new camp in southern Tanzania&#x2019;s Selous Game Reserve, home to large concentrations of elephant, wild dog and leopard; while Ruaha, one of Tanzania&#x2019;s largest yet least visited national parks, is now home to Nomad&#x2019;s new Kigelia camp and Asilia&#x2019;s Kwihala. Not to be outdone by its bush brethren, the alluring isle of Zanzibar is scaling up its luxury hotel offerings in the form of the coming <a href="http://zanzibar.park.hyatt.com/en/hotel/home.html">Park Hyatt Zanzibar</a>.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Sarah Khan</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: Game crossing the Serengeti. </span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              And Beyond
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="tanzania" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/tanzania-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=tanzania" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Tanzania">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Tanzania is No. 17 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/tanzania-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Tanzania" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Tanzania: A safari revival in troubled times. / #17 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/tanzania-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Tanzania">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>

  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">17.</span> Tanzania</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"
          itemprop="associatedMedia"
          itemscope=""
          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/tanzania-900.jpg"
          itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"
          aria-label="media"
          role="group">
          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
          <noscript>
            <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/tanzania-900.jpg" alt="Photo of Tanzania">
          </noscript>
          <img 
id="g-media-tanzania_88"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/tanzania-{{size}}.jpg"

                  And Beyond
              </span>
          </figcaption>

        <!-- Video -->
        

      </div> <!-- .g-media -->
    </div> <!-- .g-media-container -->

    
    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">A safari revival in troubled times.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>Security fears in neighboring Kenya have inadvertently worked in Tanzania&#x2019;s favor, as far as tourism goes: Its luxurious new lodges are enticing diverted visitors. The ever-popular Serengeti retains its cachet with high-profile openings. <a href="http://asiliaafrica.com/">Asilia Africa</a>&#x2019;s secluded Namiri Plains property and roving mobile camp Kimondo opened in July, followed by <a href="http://www.legendaryexpeditions.com">Legendary Expeditions</a>&#x2019; Mwiba Tented Camp in August, and a revamp of <a href="http://andbeyond.com">&amp;Beyond Grumeti</a> Tented Camp is slated to be unveiled this April. But the real new treasure here is unprecedented access to sparsely trafficked regions. <a href="http://nomad-tanzania.com/">Nomad Tanzania</a> opened Kuro amid the baobab-studded landscapes of Tarangire; Azura opened a new camp in southern Tanzania&#x2019;s Selous Game Reserve, home to large concentrations of elephant, wild dog and leopard; while Ruaha, one of Tanzania&#x2019;s largest yet least visited national parks, is now home to Nomad&#x2019;s new Kigelia camp and Asilia&#x2019;s Kwihala. Not to be outdone by its bush brethren, the alluring isle of Zanzibar is scaling up its luxury hotel offerings in the form of the coming <a href="http://zanzibar.park.hyatt.com/en/hotel/home.html">Park Hyatt Zanzibar</a>.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Sarah Khan</span></p>

  <li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/travel/guides/africa/tanzania/overview.html"><span>Related:</span> Recent Tanzania Coverage</a></li>
</ul>
