      <div id="g-story-papuanewguinea" class="g-story "
  data-slug="papuanewguinea">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-papuanewguinea_149"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/papuanewguinea-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">29.</span> Papua New Guinea</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">One of the Pacific’s most isolated corners opens up.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>This island nation has long been off the radar for most visitors, mainly because of the difficulty of getting there. Tourism is set to boom, however, now that the country has begun welcoming mega-cruise ships. <a href="http://www.pocruises.com.au/">P &amp; O Cruises</a> docked its first 2,000-passenger ship in the turquoise waters of Milne Bay on the southeastern coast in late 2013, and this year it is expanding its Papua New Guinea fleet and adding several new destinations, including Madang province, a popular diving spot. In remote areas, more eco-lodges are popping up, as well, such as the <a href="http://pngtours.com/lakemurray.html">Lake Murray Lodge,</a> a rustic retreat that opened last June on the shores of the country&#x2019;s largest lake, a bird-watching paradise.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Justin Bergman</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: Mount Hagen in the Western Highlands. </span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Mirjam Evers
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="papuanewguinea" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/papuanewguinea-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=papuanewguinea" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Papua New Guinea">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Papua New Guinea is No. 29 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/papuanewguinea-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Papua New Guinea" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Papua New Guinea: One of the Pacific’s most isolated corners opens up. / #29 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/papuanewguinea-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Papua New Guinea">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>

    </li>
  </ul>

      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825402567516849">Do you know Papua New Guinea? Tell us what to see.
</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825402567516849">On Facebook, a reader said:  “Don't forget walking the Kokoda Track! Many Aussies consider it the ultimate personal challenge.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>
  

    </div>
  </div>


  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">29.</span> Papua New Guinea</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"

      </div> <!-- .g-media -->
    </div> <!-- .g-media-container -->

    
    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">One of the Pacific’s most isolated corners opens up.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>This island nation has long been off the radar for most visitors, mainly because of the difficulty of getting there. Tourism is set to boom, however, now that the country has begun welcoming mega-cruise ships. <a href="http://www.pocruises.com.au/">P &amp; O Cruises</a> docked its first 2,000-passenger ship in the turquoise waters of Milne Bay on the southeastern coast in late 2013, and this year it is expanding its Papua New Guinea fleet and adding several new destinations, including Madang province, a popular diving spot. In remote areas, more eco-lodges are popping up, as well, such as the <a href="http://pngtours.com/lakemurray.html">Lake Murray Lodge,</a> a rustic retreat that opened last June on the shores of the country&#x2019;s largest lake, a bird-watching paradise.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Justin Bergman</span></p>

      <div id="g-story-bend" class="g-story g-hasVideo"
  data-slug="bend">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-bend_154"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/bend-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">30.</span> Bend, Oregon</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">New trails and ales beckon.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>Once a frontier logging town called Farewell Bend, this picturesque city of 80,000 is a seductive spot for travelers who are into craft brewing and the great outdoors. The Bend region has 26 breweries, three wineries, two craft spirit distilleries, two cideries and the<a href="http://www.cyclepub.com/"> Cycle Pub</a>, a tour that allows visitors to quaff craft beers while powering a sort of mobile pub by cycling. Two new distilleries,<a href="http://cascadealchemy.com/"> Cascade Alchemy</a> and<a href="http://www.backdropdistilling.com/"> Backdrop</a>, and a new cidery,<a href="http://www.farafieldcider.com/"> Far Afield</a>, are set to open this year. Bend has nearly 300 miles of single-track mountain bike<a href="http://cotamtb.com/"> trails</a>, including two new ones, Tyler&#x2019;s Traverse and Duodenum; a soon-to-open <a href="http://www.bendbulletin.com/outdoors/2647555-151/fat-bike-trails-coming-to-central-oregon">fat-bike trai</a>l (at Wanoga Sno-Park); world-class skiing at<a href="http://www.mtbachelor.com/site/index.html"> Mount Bachelor</a>; and an embarrassment of riches for hikers, fishermen, climbers, stand-up paddle boarders and kayakers.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Dave Seminara</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: The Crooked River in Smith Rock State Park.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Tyler Roemer for The New York Times
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="bend" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/bend-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=bend" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Bend, Oregon">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Bend, Oregon is No. 30 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/bend-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Bend, Oregon" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Bend, Oregon: New trails and ales beckon. / #30 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/bend-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Bend, Oregon">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>

  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">30.</span> Bend, Oregon</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->

    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">New trails and ales beckon.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>Once a frontier logging town called Farewell Bend, this picturesque city of 80,000 is a seductive spot for travelers who are into craft brewing and the great outdoors. The Bend region has 26 breweries, three wineries, two craft spirit distilleries, two cideries and the<a href="http://www.cyclepub.com/"> Cycle Pub</a>, a tour that allows visitors to quaff craft beers while powering a sort of mobile pub by cycling. Two new distilleries,<a href="http://cascadealchemy.com/"> Cascade Alchemy</a> and<a href="http://www.backdropdistilling.com/"> Backdrop</a>, and a new cidery,<a href="http://www.farafieldcider.com/"> Far Afield</a>, are set to open this year. Bend has nearly 300 miles of single-track mountain bike<a href="http://cotamtb.com/"> trails</a>, including two new ones, Tyler&#x2019;s Traverse and Duodenum; a soon-to-open <a href="http://www.bendbulletin.com/outdoors/2647555-151/fat-bike-trails-coming-to-central-oregon">fat-bike trai</a>l (at Wanoga Sno-Park); world-class skiing at<a href="http://www.mtbachelor.com/site/index.html"> Mount Bachelor</a>; and an embarrassment of riches for hikers, fishermen, climbers, stand-up paddle boarders and kayakers.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Dave Seminara</span></p>

      <div id="g-story-rabat" class="g-story "
  data-slug="rabat">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-rabat_159"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/rabat-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">31.</span> Rabat, Morocco</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">A seaside spot on the rise.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>&#xAD;Long overshadowed by the Hollywood luster of Casablanca and the storybook Moorish cities Fez and Marrakesh, this seaside metropolis &#x2014; the capital of Morocco and a <a href="http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1401">Unesco World Heritage site since 2012</a> &#x2014; is finally in the limelight. The city, with its Roman ruins, labyrinthine medieval districts, European-style boulevards, recently expanded airport and sleek modern tram system, got another boost this fall with the long-awaited opening of the<a href="http://www.museemohammed6.ma/"> Mus&#xE9;e Mohammed VI</a>, the nation&#x2019;s first modern and contemporary art museum. A much-anticipated Ritz-Carlton resort is to open in late 2015, so Rabat is set for a style infusion, as well.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Seth Sherwood</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: Rabat, a World Heritage site. </span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Yuri Kozyrev/NOOR, via Redux
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="rabat" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/rabat-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=rabat" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Rabat, Morocco">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Rabat, Morocco is No. 31 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/rabat-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Rabat, Morocco" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Rabat, Morocco: A seaside spot on the rise. / #31 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/rabat-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Rabat, Morocco">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>

    </li>

      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825403497516756">Do you know Rabat? Tell us what to see.</a>

      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825403497516756">On Facebook, a reader said:  “You have to go to the Chellah, a beautiful & quiet place that will transport you to the old times...” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>
  

    </div>
  </div>


  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">31.</span> Rabat, Morocco</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"
          itemprop="associatedMedia"
          itemscope=""
          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/rabat-900.jpg"
          itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"
          aria-label="media"
          role="group">
          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
          <noscript>
            <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/rabat-900.jpg" alt="Photo of Rabat, Morocco">
          </noscript>
          <img 
id="g-media-rabat_158"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/rabat-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 640, 720, 900, 1254, 1600, 2200, 2600]"
>
          <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
              <span class="g-caption-text">Rabat, a World Heritage site. </span>
              <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
                  <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
                  Yuri Kozyrev/NOOR, via Redux
              </span>
          </figcaption>
        </figure>

        <!-- Video -->
        

      </div> <!-- .g-media -->
    </div> <!-- .g-media-container -->

    
    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">A seaside spot on the rise.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>&#xAD;Long overshadowed by the Hollywood luster of Casablanca and the storybook Moorish cities Fez and Marrakesh, this seaside metropolis &#x2014; the capital of Morocco and a <a href="http://whc.unesco.org/en/list/1401">Unesco World Heritage site since 2012</a> &#x2014; is finally in the limelight. The city, with its Roman ruins, labyrinthine medieval districts, European-style boulevards, recently expanded airport and sleek modern tram system, got another boost this fall with the long-awaited opening of the<a href="http://www.museemohammed6.ma/"> Mus&#xE9;e Mohammed VI</a>, the nation&#x2019;s first modern and contemporary art museum. A much-anticipated Ritz-Carlton resort is to open in late 2015, so Rabat is set for a style infusion, as well.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Seth Sherwood</span></p>
        
<ul class="g-related">
  <li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/travel/guides/africa/morocco/overview.html"><span>Related:</span> Recent Morocco Coverage</a></li>
</ul>


        

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="rabat" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/rabat-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=rabat" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Rabat, Morocco">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Rabat, Morocco is No. 31 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/rabat-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Rabat, Morocco" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>

      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>

      <div id="g-story-squamish" class="g-story "
  data-slug="squamish">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-squamish_164"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/squamish-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">32.</span> Squamish, Canada</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">A mountain town now more than a stopover.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>&#xAD;Can a $22 million gondola put a Canadian mountain town on the world map? Maybe. An hour&#x2019;s drive north of Vancouver, Squamish has long been a pit stop for the 9.5 million travelers who go to Whistler ski resort each year. But last spring, the new<a href="http://s.bl-1.com/h/kY2hXn8"> Sea to Sky Gondola</a> began shuttling passengers nearly 3,000 feet from sea level to a perch in the surrounding Coast Mountains. Already, nearly a half-million people have made the ascent. Many are sticking around after the ride down, drawn by an unusual combination of West Coast wilderness and accessibility. Hundreds of trails weave through Pacific rain forest to glacial lakes, waterfalls and peaks. Kiteboarders ply a 26-mile fjord, adventurers climb 2,300-foot Stawamus Chief, and birders gather for the annual return of<a href="http://s.bl-1.com/h/kY2jnyG"> thousands of bald eagles</a>.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Remy Scalza</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: Visitors wait for a rare show of northern lights at Porteau Cove, outside Squamish.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Remy Scalza
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="squamish" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/squamish-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=squamish" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Squamish, Canada">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Squamish, Canada is No. 32 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/squamish-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Squamish, Canada" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Squamish, Canada: A mountain town now more than a stopover. / #32 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/squamish-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Squamish, Canada">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">A mountain town now more than a stopover.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>&#xAD;Can a $22 million gondola put a Canadian mountain town on the world map? Maybe. An hour&#x2019;s drive north of Vancouver, Squamish has long been a pit stop for the 9.5 million travelers who go to Whistler ski resort each year. But last spring, the new<a href="http://s.bl-1.com/h/kY2hXn8"> Sea to Sky Gondola</a> began shuttling passengers nearly 3,000 feet from sea level to a perch in the surrounding Coast Mountains. Already, nearly a half-million people have made the ascent. Many are sticking around after the ride down, drawn by an unusual combination of West Coast wilderness and accessibility. Hundreds of trails weave through Pacific rain forest to glacial lakes, waterfalls and peaks. Kiteboarders ply a 26-mile fjord, adventurers climb 2,300-foot Stawamus Chief, and birders gather for the annual return of<a href="http://s.bl-1.com/h/kY2jnyG"> thousands of bald eagles</a>.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Remy Scalza</span></p>

      <div id="g-story-seoul" class="g-story g-hasVideo"
  data-slug="seoul">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-seoul_169"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/seoul-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">33.</span> Seoul, South Korea</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">Over a million new square feet of art, architecture and design.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>&#xAD;In 2014 the <a href="http://www.ddp.or.kr/MA010001/getInitPage.do">Dongdaemun Design Plaza</a> alighted like a silver spaceship in a gritty old shopping neighborhood in the South Korean capital. Designed by the Pritzker-prize-winning architect <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/h/zaha_hadid/index.html">Zaha Hadid</a>, the 900,000-square-foot, neo-futuristic, curvilinear exhibition space has helped transform the area around it into an international design hub. Visual-arts-minded visitors should also check out the 560,000-square-foot Seoul branch of the<a href="http://www.mmca.go.kr/eng/"> National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art</a>, opened in 2013 with the aim of being to the Korean capital what the Museum of Modern Art is to New York City, and the new 121,000-square-foot <a href="http://asemus.museum/museum/national-hangeul-museum-korea/">National Hangeul Museum</a>, which is dedicated to the much-admired, ultra-rational Korean alphabet.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Elisabeth Eaves</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: The Dongdaemun Design Plaza.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Jean Chung for The New York Times
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="seoul" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/seoul-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=seoul" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Seoul, South Korea">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Seoul, South Korea is No. 33 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/seoul-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Seoul, South Korea" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Seoul, South Korea: Over a million new square feet of art, architecture and design. / #33 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/seoul-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Seoul, South Korea">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>



      
  
  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825403897516716">Do you know Seoul? Tell us what to see.</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825403897516716">On Facebook, a reader said:  “Best place for coffee and dessert: Anie Chocho. Make sure you try her tiny pies, baked in a cast iron skillet.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>
  

    </div>
  </div>


  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">33.</span> Seoul, South Korea</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"
          itemprop="associatedMedia"
          itemscope=""
          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/seoul-900.jpg"
          itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"
          aria-label="media"
          role="group">
          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
          <noscript>
            <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/seoul-900.jpg" alt="Photo of Seoul, South Korea">
          </noscript>
          <img 
id="g-media-seoul_168"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/seoul-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 640, 720, 900, 1254, 1600, 2200, 2600]"
>
          <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
              <span class="g-caption-text">The Dongdaemun Design Plaza.</span>
              <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
                  <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
                  Jean Chung for The New York Times
              </span>
          </figcaption>
        </figure>

        <!-- Video -->
        
          <figure
            class="g-figure-video"
            itemprop="associatedMedia"
            itemscope=""
            itemid=""
            itemtype="http://schema.org/VideoObject"
            aria-label="media"
            role="group">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Video Player</span>
            <noscript>
              <video autoplay="" loop="" muted="" preload="none" poster="">
                  <source id="mp4" src="" type="video/mp4">
                  <img src="">
              </video>
            </noscript>
            <!-- laziestloader container -->
<div 
id="g-media-seoul_171"
data-ratio="0.66666667"
data-slug="seoul"
class="g-lazy-video g-lazy-media">
  <!-- vhs container -->
  <div id="g-media-seoul_171_vhs" class="g-vhs"></div>
</div>

            <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="g-caption-text">The Dongdaemun Design Plaza.</span>
                <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
                    <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
                    Jean Chung for The New York Times
                </span>
            </figcaption>
          </figure>
        

      </div> <!-- .g-media -->
    </div> <!-- .g-media-container -->

    
    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">Over a million new square feet of art, architecture and design.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>&#xAD;In 2014 the <a href="http://www.ddp.or.kr/MA010001/getInitPage.do">Dongdaemun Design Plaza</a> alighted like a silver spaceship in a gritty old shopping neighborhood in the South Korean capital. Designed by the Pritzker-prize-winning architect <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/h/zaha_hadid/index.html">Zaha Hadid</a>, the 900,000-square-foot, neo-futuristic, curvilinear exhibition space has helped transform the area around it into an international design hub. Visual-arts-minded visitors should also check out the 560,000-square-foot Seoul branch of the<a href="http://www.mmca.go.kr/eng/"> National Museum of Modern and Contemporary Art</a>, opened in 2013 with the aim of being to the Korean capital what the Museum of Modern Art is to New York City, and the new 121,000-square-foot <a href="http://asemus.museum/museum/national-hangeul-museum-korea/">National Hangeul Museum</a>, which is dedicated to the much-admired, ultra-rational Korean alphabet.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Elisabeth Eaves</span></p>
        
<ul class="g-related">
  <li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/travel/guides/asia/south-korea/seoul/overview.html"><span>Related:</span> Recent Seoul Coverage</a></li>
</ul>


        

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="seoul" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/seoul-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=seoul" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Seoul, South Korea">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Seoul, South Korea is No. 33 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/seoul-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Seoul, South Korea" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">

      <div id="g-story-stkitts" class="g-story "
  data-slug="stkitts">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-stkitts_174"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/stkitts-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">34.</span> St. Kitts</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">Upscale in the Caribbean, but sustainable, too.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>&#xAD;The 65-square-mile island of St. Kitts is best known for its annual music festival, with performers ranging from Michael Bolton to Nas. Now two landmark hotel developments will put this lush, unpretentious island on the map for luxury. In the south, <a href="http://ChristopheHarbour.com">Christophe Harbour</a> &#x2014; a grand development featuring a new mega-yacht marina, Tom Fazio golf course and trendy beach club, SALT Plage &#x2014; will in 2015 break ground on the Caribbean&#x2019;s first Park Hyatt. Transforming the mountainous north, meanwhile, is <a href="http://KittitianHill.com">Kittitian Hill</a> &#x2014; not just a lavish resort but a sustainable community, honoring all things local, with a 400-acre organic farm, &quot;edible&quot; golf course on a former marijuana farm, plush accommodations and farm-to-table cuisine. There are even plans for a film institute, fine art residency program and weekly fish fry. The airport&#x2019;s plush <a href="http://YuLounge.com">YU Lounge</a>, a private jet terminal that opened this year, will make the influx of upscale travelers feel right at home.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">BAZ DREISINGER</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: Kittitian Hill.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Jean-Philippe Piter
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="stkitts" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/stkitts-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=stkitts" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: St. Kitts">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? St. Kitts is No. 34 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/stkitts-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: St. Kitts" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>

      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: St. Kitts">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>

    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">Upscale in the Caribbean, but sustainable, too.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>&#xAD;The 65-square-mile island of St. Kitts is best known for its annual music festival, with performers ranging from Michael Bolton to Nas. Now two landmark hotel developments will put this lush, unpretentious island on the map for luxury. In the south, <a href="http://ChristopheHarbour.com">Christophe Harbour</a> &#x2014; a grand development featuring a new mega-yacht marina, Tom Fazio golf course and trendy beach club, SALT Plage &#x2014; will in 2015 break ground on the Caribbean&#x2019;s first Park Hyatt. Transforming the mountainous north, meanwhile, is <a href="http://KittitianHill.com">Kittitian Hill</a> &#x2014; not just a lavish resort but a sustainable community, honoring all things local, with a 400-acre organic farm, &quot;edible&quot; golf course on a former marijuana farm, plush accommodations and farm-to-table cuisine. There are even plans for a film institute, fine art residency program and weekly fish fry. The airport&#x2019;s plush <a href="http://YuLounge.com">YU Lounge</a>, a private jet terminal that opened this year, will make the influx of upscale travelers feel right at home.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">BAZ DREISINGER</span></p>

      <div id="g-story-shikoku" class="g-story "
  data-slug="shikoku">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-shikoku_179"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/shikoku-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">35.</span> Shikoku, Japan</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">Anniversaries abound on Japan’s smallest main island.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>Shikoku, the smallest of Japan&#x2019;s four main islands, is the site of a pilgrimage trail established in 815 that winds past 88 temples. Since celebrations of the ancient route&#x2019;s 1,200th anniversary were held last year, the 750-mile trail can be enjoyed in relative peace. One particular stop of note is the city of Matsuyama. It is home to several of the temples and the castle-like Dogo Onsen bathhouse, which at 120 years old is one of the country&#x2019;s oldest natural hot-spring public baths. And a new Japan Rail pass, released to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the high-speed Tokaido Shinkansen, will make traveling between Tokyo and the island by train even easier this year.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Ingrid K. Williams</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: Iwayaji Temple on the island. </span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              JTB/UIG, via Getty Images
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="shikoku" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/shikoku-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=shikoku" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Shikoku, Japan">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Shikoku, Japan is No. 35 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/shikoku-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Shikoku, Japan" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>

      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Shikoku, Japan">

  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825404667516639">What did we miss in Shikoku? Share your tips.
</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825404667516639">On Facebook, a reader said:  “Saijo city has an impressive Matusri every fall (October 14-17). Dozens of Danjiri are carried by hand through the famously clear and cold waters of the Kamo river“ <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>

  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">35.</span> Shikoku, Japan</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"
          itemprop="associatedMedia"
          itemscope=""
          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/shikoku-900.jpg"
          itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"
          aria-label="media"
          role="group">
          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
          <noscript>
            <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/shikoku-900.jpg" alt="Photo of Shikoku, Japan">
          </noscript>
          <img 
id="g-media-shikoku_178"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/shikoku-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 640, 720, 900, 1254, 1600, 2200, 2600]"
>
          <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
              <span class="g-caption-text">Iwayaji Temple on the island. </span>
              <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
                  <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
                  JTB/UIG, via Getty Images
              </span>
          </figcaption>
        </figure>

        <!-- Video -->
        

      </div> <!-- .g-media -->
    </div> <!-- .g-media-container -->

    
    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">Anniversaries abound on Japan’s smallest main island.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>Shikoku, the smallest of Japan&#x2019;s four main islands, is the site of a pilgrimage trail established in 815 that winds past 88 temples. Since celebrations of the ancient route&#x2019;s 1,200th anniversary were held last year, the 750-mile trail can be enjoyed in relative peace. One particular stop of note is the city of Matsuyama. It is home to several of the temples and the castle-like Dogo Onsen bathhouse, which at 120 years old is one of the country&#x2019;s oldest natural hot-spring public baths. And a new Japan Rail pass, released to commemorate the 50th anniversary of the high-speed Tokaido Shinkansen, will make traveling between Tokyo and the island by train even easier this year.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Ingrid K. Williams</span></p>
        
<ul class="g-related">
  <li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/travel/guides/asia/japan/overview.html"><span>Related:</span> Recent Japan Coverage</a></li>
</ul>

    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Shikoku, Japan is No. 35 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/shikoku-900.jpg">

      <div id="g-story-sanantonio" class="g-story g-hasVideo"
  data-slug="sanantonio">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-sanantonio_184"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/sanantonio-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">36.</span> San Antonio</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">New attractions and renewed cultural depth.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>&#xAD;San Antonio&#x2019;s riverside promenade,<a href="http://www.thesanantonioriverwalk.com/"> River Walk</a>, one of Texas&#x2019;s most visited attractions, was expanded in 2013 from three to 15 miles, linking to four of the city&#x2019;s historic Spanish colonial missions, a $358 million investment that has inspired a path-side development boom. In late 2013, the<a href="http://www.briscoemuseum.org/"> Briscoe Western Art Museum</a> opened in the former San Antonio Library. Last September, the<a href="https://www.tobincenter.org/"> Tobin Center for the Performing Arts</a>, host venue to the San Antonio Symphony and nine other cultural institutions, joined the River Walk, adding an outdoor performance plaza, 30-foot video wall and water-taxi stand. The River Walk now reaches the redeveloped Pearl Brewery, home to restaurants, a cooking school and, in spring, the 146-room<a href="http://www.thehotelemma.com/renovation.html"> Hotel Emma</a> from Kimpton Hotels.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Elaine Glusac</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: The city's River Walk. </span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Malú Alvarez for The New York Times
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="sanantonio" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/sanantonio-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=sanantonio" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: San Antonio">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? San Antonio is No. 36 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/sanantonio-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>

      <div id="g-story-sanjose" class="g-story "
  data-slug="sanjose">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-sanjose_189"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/sanjose-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">37.</span> San José del Cabo, Mexico</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">A historic Baja city bounces back in style.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>The two cabos &#x2014; capes &#x2014; that make up Los Cabos offer equal access to sun and sea, but San Jos&#xE9; del Cabo feels mellower than its sibling city, Cabo San Lucas. Yet it is developing an increasingly appealing dining and hotel scene. In September, the organic farm, restaurant and hotel<a href="http://www.flora-farms.com/"> Flora Farms</a> lured Aaron Abramson away from the celebrated Blue Hill at Stone Barns in New York, and in November it opened a store selling its own meat and produce in the city&#x2019;s central historic district. A block away, the stylishly minimalist eight-room hotel<a href="http://www.driftsanjose.com/"> Drift</a> also opened its doors last year. Both of the cabos are coaxing visitors back with discounts after Hurricane Odile wreaked havoc last fall.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Elisabeth Eaves</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: Flora Farms. </span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Rigoberto Moreno
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="sanjose" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/sanjose-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=sanjose" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: San José del Cabo, Mexico">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? San José del Cabo, Mexico is No. 37 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/sanjose-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: San José del Cabo, Mexico" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="San José del Cabo, Mexico: A historic Baja city bounces back in style. / #37 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/sanjose-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: San José del Cabo, Mexico">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>

  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825405910849848">What did we miss in San José del Cabo? Share your tips.</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825405910849848">On Facebook, a reader said:  “Thursday night art walks, organic markets, sunsets, great people. It gets under your skin. Hard to leave.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>

  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">37.</span> San José del Cabo, Mexico</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"
          itemprop="associatedMedia"
          itemscope=""
          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/sanjose-900.jpg"
          itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"
          aria-label="media"
          role="group">
          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
          <noscript>
            <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/sanjose-900.jpg" alt="Photo of San José del Cabo, Mexico">
          </noscript>
          <img 
id="g-media-sanjose_188"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/sanjose-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 640, 720, 900, 1254, 1600, 2200, 2600]"
>
          <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
              <span class="g-caption-text">Flora Farms. </span>
              <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
                  <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
                  Rigoberto Moreno
              </span>
          </figcaption>
        </figure>

        <!-- Video -->
        

      </div> <!-- .g-media -->
    </div> <!-- .g-media-container -->

    
    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">A historic Baja city bounces back in style.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>The two cabos &#x2014; capes &#x2014; that make up Los Cabos offer equal access to sun and sea, but San Jos&#xE9; del Cabo feels mellower than its sibling city, Cabo San Lucas. Yet it is developing an increasingly appealing dining and hotel scene. In September, the organic farm, restaurant and hotel<a href="http://www.flora-farms.com/"> Flora Farms</a> lured Aaron Abramson away from the celebrated Blue Hill at Stone Barns in New York, and in November it opened a store selling its own meat and produce in the city&#x2019;s central historic district. A block away, the stylishly minimalist eight-room hotel<a href="http://www.driftsanjose.com/"> Drift</a> also opened its doors last year. Both of the cabos are coaxing visitors back with discounts after Hurricane Odile wreaked havoc last fall.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Elisabeth Eaves</span></p>
        
<ul class="g-related">
  <li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/03/15/travel/what-to-do-in-36-hours-in-los-cabos-mexico.html"><span>Related:</span> "What to Do in Los Cabos, Mexico"</a></li>
</ul>


        

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="sanjose" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/sanjose-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=sanjose" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: San José del Cabo, Mexico">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? San José del Cabo, Mexico is No. 37 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/sanjose-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: San José del Cabo, Mexico" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="San José del Cabo, Mexico: A historic Baja city bounces back in style. / #37 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/sanjose-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>

  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825405910849848">What did we miss in San José del Cabo? Share your tips.</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825405910849848">On Facebook, a reader said:  “Thursday night art walks, organic markets, sunsets, great people. It gets under your skin. Hard to leave.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>

      <div id="g-story-alentejo" class="g-story "
  data-slug="alentejo">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-alentejo_194"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/alentejo-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">38.</span> Alentejo, Portugal</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">Bored With Bordeaux? Tired of Tuscany?</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>&quot;Wine is nectar for a sweet life&quot; reads a quote on the wall of the new<a href="http://www.torredepalma.com/en/"> Torre de Palma, Wine Hotel</a>, which opened last year in the Portuguese region of Alentejo. If so, then Alentejo &#x2014; a big-sky expanse of grain fields, olive groves, cork forests and vineyards &#x2014; is in a sweet spot indeed. Chic wine-themed hotels and resorts have been sprouting in bunches, showcasing the area&#x2019;s complex red wines and sun-baked terroir. The <a href="http://www.malhadinhanova.pt/en/"> Malhadinha Nova</a> hotel and spa pairs its wines with cured hams from black pigs raised on its grounds, while the seaside<a href="http://www.herdadedacomporta.pt/en/wine/cellar/"> Herdade da Comporta</a> serves up beach and golf alongside its vineyards. For design buffs, the three-year-old <a href="http://l-andvineyards.com/en/"> L&#x2019;AND Vineyards</a> resort has interiors designed by the Brazilian architect Marcio Kogan, a Caudalie wine spa, a Michelin-starred restaurant, and suites with retractable roofs for viewing the real stars. An homage to wine&#x2019;s constant companion (and a regional staple), the two-year-old <a href="http://www.ecorkhotel.com/">Ecorkhotel</a> bills itself as the world&#x2019;s first cork-covered hotel, complete with chromatherapy spa and an &quot;eno-gastronomic&quot; restaurant. With the opening this fall of L&#x2019;AND Reserve &#x2014; a bolder wine resort with nearly 40 more such suites &#x2014; the sky&#x2019;s the limit.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Seth Sherwood</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: The Ecorkhotel in the Évora district.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Fernando Guerra
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="alentejo" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/alentejo-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=alentejo" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Alentejo, Portugal">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Alentejo, Portugal is No. 38 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/alentejo-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Alentejo, Portugal" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Alentejo, Portugal: Bored With Bordeaux? Tired of Tuscany? / #38 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/alentejo-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Alentejo, Portugal">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>



      
  
  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825405454183227">What are your favorite things to do in Alentejo?</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825405454183227">On Facebook, a reader said:  “Évora is a lovely UNESCO World Heritage Site with the oldest Roman ruins in Portugal.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>
  

    </div>
  </div>


  <!-- EXPANDED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">38.</span> Alentejo, Portugal</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"
          itemprop="associatedMedia"
          itemscope=""
          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/alentejo-900.jpg"
          itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"
          aria-label="media"
          role="group">
          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
          <noscript>
            <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/alentejo-900.jpg" alt="Photo of Alentejo, Portugal">

    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">Bored With Bordeaux? Tired of Tuscany?</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>&quot;Wine is nectar for a sweet life&quot; reads a quote on the wall of the new<a href="http://www.torredepalma.com/en/"> Torre de Palma, Wine Hotel</a>, which opened last year in the Portuguese region of Alentejo. If so, then Alentejo &#x2014; a big-sky expanse of grain fields, olive groves, cork forests and vineyards &#x2014; is in a sweet spot indeed. Chic wine-themed hotels and resorts have been sprouting in bunches, showcasing the area&#x2019;s complex red wines and sun-baked terroir. The <a href="http://www.malhadinhanova.pt/en/"> Malhadinha Nova</a> hotel and spa pairs its wines with cured hams from black pigs raised on its grounds, while the seaside<a href="http://www.herdadedacomporta.pt/en/wine/cellar/"> Herdade da Comporta</a> serves up beach and golf alongside its vineyards. For design buffs, the three-year-old <a href="http://l-andvineyards.com/en/"> L&#x2019;AND Vineyards</a> resort has interiors designed by the Brazilian architect Marcio Kogan, a Caudalie wine spa, a Michelin-starred restaurant, and suites with retractable roofs for viewing the real stars. An homage to wine&#x2019;s constant companion (and a regional staple), the two-year-old <a href="http://www.ecorkhotel.com/">Ecorkhotel</a> bills itself as the world&#x2019;s first cork-covered hotel, complete with chromatherapy spa and an &quot;eno-gastronomic&quot; restaurant. With the opening this fall of L&#x2019;AND Reserve &#x2014; a bolder wine resort with nearly 40 more such suites &#x2014; the sky&#x2019;s the limit.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Seth Sherwood</span></p>
        
<ul class="g-related">
  <li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2015/01/18/travel/in-portugal-a-land-finely-aged-like-wine.html"><span>Related:</span> "In Portugal, a Land Finely Aged Like Wine"</a></li>
</ul>


        

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="alentejo" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/alentejo-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=alentejo" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Alentejo, Portugal">

      <div id="g-story-catskills" class="g-story "
  data-slug="catskills">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-catskills_199"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/catskills-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">39.</span> The Catskills, New York</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">Not your Bubbie and Zadie’s getaway.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>Something funny is happening in this mountainous region 100 miles north of New York City, where Jewish comedians like Woody Allen once performed at Borscht Belt resorts: The Catskills are being reshaped by a new generation of fresh-air-seeking urbanites. On summer weekends the tiny hamlet of Phoenicia resembles Williamsburg North, with pilgrims drawn by the <a href="http://www.thegrahamandco.com/">Graham &amp; Co.</a>, a 20-room hotel started by four Brooklynites, and the local favorite, <a href="http://www.phoeniciadiner.com/">Phoenicia Diner</a>. And with<a href="http://www.vogue.com/slideshow/2481771/woodstock-new-york-travel-guide/"> Vogue-approved</a> spots like the Italian restaurant Cucina and short-stay cabins <a href="http://www.woodstockway.com/">Woodstock Way</a>, Woodstock has moved beyond its tie-dyed hippie image. What hasn&#x2019;t changed is the abundance of outdoor activities: world-class trout fishing, rafting on Esopus Creek and skiing at Hunter Mountain and Belleayre Ski Center.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Steven Kurutz</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: The Graham & Co., a popular hotel in Phoenicia, N.Y.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Brandon Harman
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="catskills" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/catskills-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=catskills" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: The Catskills, New York">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? The Catskills, New York is No. 39 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/catskills-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: The Catskills, New York" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="The Catskills, New York: Not your Bubbie and Zadie’s getaway. / #39 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/catskills-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share email" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: The Catskills, New York">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-email-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
  </ul>



      
  
  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825407047516401">What did we miss in the Catskills? Share your tips.</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825407047516401">On Facebook, a reader said:  “Fall Foliage train rides along the esopus river on the Catskill Mountain Railroad in Mt Tremper NY.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>
    
  </div>

  <div class="g-view-expanded">
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">39.</span> The Catskills, New York</h3>

    <div class="g-media-container">
      <div class="g-media">

        <!-- Image -->
        <figure
          class="g-figure-image"
          itemprop="associatedMedia"
          itemscope=""
          itemid="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/catskills-900.jpg"
          itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject"
          aria-label="media"
          role="group">
          <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
          <noscript>
            <img src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/catskills-900.jpg" alt="Photo of The Catskills, New York">
          </noscript>
          <img

                  Brandon Harman
              </span>
          </figcaption>
        </figure>

        <!-- Video -->
        

      </div> <!-- .g-media -->
    </div> <!-- .g-media-container -->

    
    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">Not your Bubbie and Zadie’s getaway.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>Something funny is happening in this mountainous region 100 miles north of New York City, where Jewish comedians like Woody Allen once performed at Borscht Belt resorts: The Catskills are being reshaped by a new generation of fresh-air-seeking urbanites. On summer weekends the tiny hamlet of Phoenicia resembles Williamsburg North, with pilgrims drawn by the <a href="http://www.thegrahamandco.com/">Graham &amp; Co.</a>, a 20-room hotel started by four Brooklynites, and the local favorite, <a href="http://www.phoeniciadiner.com/">Phoenicia Diner</a>. And with<a href="http://www.vogue.com/slideshow/2481771/woodstock-new-york-travel-guide/"> Vogue-approved</a> spots like the Italian restaurant Cucina and short-stay cabins <a href="http://www.woodstockway.com/">Woodstock Way</a>, Woodstock has moved beyond its tie-dyed hippie image. What hasn&#x2019;t changed is the abundance of outdoor activities: world-class trout fishing, rafting on Esopus Creek and skiing at Hunter Mountain and Belleayre Ski Center.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Steven Kurutz</span></p>
        
<ul class="g-related">
  <li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/25/nyregion/plan-b-open-a-country-hotel-in-upstate-new-york.html"><span>Related:</span> “Plan B: Open a Country Hotel in Upstate New York“</a></li>
</ul>


        

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="catskills" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/catskills-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=catskills" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: The Catskills, New York">

      <div id="g-story-quebeccity" class="g-story g-hasVideo"
  data-slug="quebeccity">

  <!-- COLLAPSED VIEW -->
  <div class="g-view-collapsed">

    <div class="g-thumb"><img 
id="g-media-quebeccity_204"
class="g-lazy-image g-lazy-media g-lazy-place"
src="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/packages/flash/multimedia/ICONS/transparent.png"
data-pattern="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/square_images/quebeccity-{{size}}.jpg"
data-widths="[240, 320, 500, 640]"
></div>
    <h3 class="g-title"><span class="g-rank">40.</span> Quebec City, Canada</h3>
    <p class="g-leadin">N.H.L. team or not, the Quebec capital is scoring.</p>
    <div class="g-expand-container">
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-expand"></div>
      <div class="g-icon g-icon-close"></div>
    </div>
    <div class="g-blurb">
      <p>Long overshadowed by nearby Montreal, Quebec City is stocking up on attractions, and seeking an N.H.L. team to again call its own. To that end, the city has been building Quebecor Arena, a state-of-the-art stadium costing an estimated $400 million to open before the 2015 season. It may take years to score an N.H.L franchise, but even without a big-time team to cheer, the capital of Quebec &#x2014; and French Canada &#x2014; has many new draws to keep visitors entertained, from the newly hip St.-Roch neighborhood to innovative restaurants serving nouveau Qu&#xE9;b&#xE9;cois cuisine to rival its neighbor&#x2019;s finest.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Ingrid K. Williams</span></p>
      <figcaption class="g-caption" itemprop="caption description">
          <span class="g-caption-text">Above: The city's Rue du Petit-Champlain.</span>
          <span class="g-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
              <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
              Joe Klementovich for The New York Times
          </span>
      </figcaption>
      

  <ul class="g-share custom-share-container" data-cs-slug="quebeccity" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/quebeccity-900.jpg" data-cs-url="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/01/11/travel/52-places-to-go-in-2015.html?placeId=quebeccity" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Quebec City, Canada">
    <li class="custom-share twitter" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015? Quebec City, Canada is No. 40 on @NYTimesTravel's list" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/images/quebeccity-900.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-twitter-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share facebook" data-cs-text="Where to go in 2015: Quebec City, Canada" data-cs-summary="Explore our list of 52 places to go in 2015, selected by New York Times Travel editors.">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-active g-active-icon"></span>
    </li>
    <li class="custom-share pinterest" data-cs-text="Quebec City, Canada: N.H.L. team or not, the Quebec capital is scoring. / #40 on @nytimes's list of 52 Places to Go in 2015" data-cs-image="http://graphics8.nytimes.com/newsgraphics/2015/01/08/places-to-go/assets/vertical_images/quebeccity-735.jpg">
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest g-inactive-icon"></span>
      <span class="g-icon g-icon-pinterest-active g-active-icon"></span>

  <div class="g-facebookthread">
    <h4>
      <a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825406577516448">Do you know Quebec City? Tell us what to see.
</a> 
    </h4>
    
      <p class="g-facebookthread-comment"><a href="https://www.facebook.com/nytimestravel/posts/825406577516448">On Facebook, a reader said:  “This is a great city for walking. Stay in a bed & breakfast, walk to the Farmers Market to buy food for lunch, go to a restaurant in the old Québec. Also take a trip out to Ile d'Orleans.” <span class="g-icon g-icon-facebook-xsmall"></span></a></p>

    <div class="g-content-container">
      <p class="g-leadin">N.H.L. team or not, the Quebec capital is scoring.</p>
      <div class="g-blurb">
        <p>Long overshadowed by nearby Montreal, Quebec City is stocking up on attractions, and seeking an N.H.L. team to again call its own. To that end, the city has been building Quebecor Arena, a state-of-the-art stadium costing an estimated $400 million to open before the 2015 season. It may take years to score an N.H.L franchise, but even without a big-time team to cheer, the capital of Quebec &#x2014; and French Canada &#x2014; has many new draws to keep visitors entertained, from the newly hip St.-Roch neighborhood to innovative restaurants serving nouveau Qu&#xE9;b&#xE9;cois cuisine to rival its neighbor&#x2019;s finest.<span class="g-reporter-space"> </span><span class="g-reporter">Ingrid K. Williams</span></p>
