<!-- Pipeline: 2015-03-09-subredwingmap | June 8, 2015, 06:27PM | e768b70854ae39892ff0bb3b8cea76652b285787 -->
<meta name='interactivegraphic:height:300' content='1170'>    </div>
    
    <div class="footer">

        
                <div class="interactive-source">
            <span class="g-graphicCutline">SEAL Team 6 headquarters in Virginia.</span> <span class="g-nowrap">By The New York Times</span> | <span class="g-nowrap">Images from U.S.D.A. and Google Earth.</span>        </div>
        
        
    </div>
</figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="415" data-total-count="15774" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-13">The <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/organizations/n/navy_seals/index.html?inline=nyt-org" title="More articles about Navy Seals." class="meta-org">Navy SEALs</a> — the acronym stands for Sea, Air, Land forces — evolved from the frogmen of World War II. Team 6 arose decades later, born out of the failed 1980 mission to rescue 53 American hostages seized in the takeover of the United States Embassy in Tehran. Poor planning and bad weather forced commanders to abort the mission, and eight servicemen died when two aircraft collided over the Iranian desert.</p><div id="MiddleRight5" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-14">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="366" data-total-count="16140" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-14">The Navy then asked Cmdr. Richard Marcinko, a hard-charging Vietnam veteran, to build a SEAL unit that could respond quickly to terrorist crises. The name itself was an attempt at Cold War disinformation: Only two SEAL teams existed at the time, but Commander Marcinko called the unit SEAL Team 6 hoping that Soviet analysts would overestimate the size of the force.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="340" data-total-count="16480" itemprop="articleBody">He flouted rules and fostered a maverick image for the unit. (Years after leaving the command, he was convicted of military contract fraud.) In his autobiography, “Rogue Warrior,” Commander Marcinko describes drinking together as important to SEAL Team 6’s solidarity; his recruiting interviews often amounted to boozy chats in a bar.</p> <figure id="inside-seal-team-six" class="interactive promo  has-adjacency layout-large">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-15">Continue reading the main story</a>
    <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2015/05/27/world/inside-seal-team-six.html">
                <figcaption class="interactive-caption">
                        <h2 class="interactive-headline">
                Inside SEAL Team 6            </h2>
            <p class="interactive-summary">
                Officially, SEAL Team 6 does not exist. The unit performs some of the military’s most dangerous missions, those considered too risky for conventional troops.            </p>
        </figcaption>
        
        <div class="interactive-image-container">
            <div class="interactive-image">
                <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/sealsnight/sealsnight-master495.jpg" />
            </div>
            <div class="interactive-overlay">
                <i class="icon sprite-icon interactive-overlay-icon"></i>
                            </div>
        </div>

            </a>
</figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="340" data-total-count="16820" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-15">Inside Team 6, there were initially two assault groups, called Blue and Gold, after the Navy colors. Blue used the Jolly Roger pirate flag as its insignia and early on earned the nickname “the Bad Boys in Blue,” for racking up drunken driving arrests, abusing narcotics and crashing rental cars on training exercises with near impunity.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="373" data-total-count="17193" itemprop="articleBody">Young officers sometimes were run out of Team 6 for trying to clean up what they perceived as a culture of recklessness. Adm. William H. McRaven, who rose to head the Special Operations Command and oversaw the Bin Laden raid, was pushed out of Team 6 and assigned to another SEAL team during the Marcinko era after complaining of difficulties in keeping his troops in line.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="576" data-total-count="17769" itemprop="articleBody">Ryan Zinke, a former Team 6 officer and now a Republican congressman from Montana, recalled an episode after a team training mission aboard a cruise liner in preparation for potential hostage rescues at the 1992 Summer Olympics in Barcelona, Spain. Mr. Zinke escorted an admiral to a bar in the ship’s lower level. “When we opened the door, it reminded me of ‘Pirates of the Caribbean,’” Mr. Zinke said, recalling that the admiral was appalled by the operators’ long hair, beards and earrings. “My Navy?” the admiral asked him. “These guys are in my Navy?”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="361" data-total-count="18130" itemprop="articleBody">That was the beginning of what Mr. Zinke referred to as “the great bloodletting,” when the Navy purged Team 6’s leadership to professionalize the force. Current and former Team 6 operators said the culture was different today. Members now tend to be better educated, more athletic, older and more mature — though some are still known for pushing limits.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="115" data-total-count="18245" itemprop="articleBody">“I got kicked out of the Boy Scouts,” said one former officer. Most Team 6 SEALs, he added, “were like me.”</p><figure id="media-100000003703830" class="media photo embedded layout-jumbo-horizontal media-100000003703830" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-sealsbw1/29seals-sealsbw1-master1050.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-sealsbw1/29seals-sealsbw1-master1050.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-sealsbw1/29seals-sealsbw1-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="A&nbsp;prospective member of the Navy SEALs with a tattoo depicting hand-to-hand combat, during dive training in Coronado, Calif." data-mediaviewer-credit="Stephanie Freid-Perenchio"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-sealsbw1/29seals-sealsbw1-master1050.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="648" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="1050" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">A prospective member of the Navy SEALs with a tattoo depicting hand-to-hand combat, during dive training in Coronado, Calif.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Stephanie Freid-Perenchio        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="347" data-total-count="18592" itemprop="articleBody">Delta Force members, who have a reputation for going by the book, often start out as regular infantry, then move up through the Army’s Ranger units and Special Forces teams before joining Delta. But SEAL Team 6 is more isolated from the rest of the Navy, with many of its men entering the brutal SEAL training pipeline from outside the military.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="292" data-total-count="18884" itemprop="articleBody">After several years on regular SEAL teams — the even-numbered ones based in Virginia Beach, the odd-numbered ones in San Diego, and a unit in Hawaii dedicated to mini-submarines — SEALs can try out for Team 6. Many are eager to get to the most elite unit, but about half of them wash out.</p><div id="MiddleRight6" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-16">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="295" data-total-count="19179" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-16">Officers rotate through Team 6, sometimes returning for several tours, but the enlisted SEALs typically stay far longer, giving them outsize influence. “A lot of the enlisted guys think that they really run the show,” said one former senior member. “That’s part of the Marcinko style.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="424" data-total-count="19603" itemprop="articleBody">And they tend to swagger, critics and defenders say. While the other SEAL teams (called “white” or “vanilla” SEALs within the military) perform similar tasks, Team 6 pursues the highest value targets and takes on hostage rescues in combat zones. It also works more with the C.I.A. and does more clandestine missions outside war zones. Only Team 6 trains to chase after nuclear weapons that fall into the wrong hands.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="658" data-total-count="20261" itemprop="articleBody">Team 6’s role in the 2011 Bin Laden raid spawned a cottage industry of books and documentaries, leaving tight-lipped Delta Force troops rolling their eyes. Members of Team 6 are expected to honor a code of silence about their missions, and many current and former members fume that two of their own spoke out about their role in the Qaeda leader’s death. The men, <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/10/31/us/former-navy-seal-matt-bissonnette-investigated-for-bin-laden-book.html">Matt Bissonnette</a>, author of two best sellers about his tenure at SEAL Team 6, and <a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2014/11/07/world/asia/another-ex-commando-says-he-shot-bin-laden.html">Robert O’Neill</a>, who said in a television special that he had killed Bin Laden, are under investigation by the Naval Criminal Investigative Service over accusations that they revealed classified information.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="328" data-total-count="20589" itemprop="articleBody">Others have been quietly kicked out for drug use or quit over conflicts of interest involving military contractors or side jobs. The Navy reprimanded 11 current and former operators in 2012 for disclosing Team 6 tactics or handing over classified training films to help promote a computer game, <a href="http://mediadecoder.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/11/09/the-breakfast-meeting-seals-punished-for-video-game-work-and-samsung-in-the-lead/">“Medal of Honor: Warfighter.”</a></p><figure id="media-100000003703917" class="media photo embedded layout-large-horizontal media-100000003703917 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-extortion17/29seals-extortion17-articleLarge.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-extortion17/29seals-extortion17-articleLarge.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-extortion17/29seals-extortion17-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="The burial site at Arlington National Cemetery for the remains of the men killed when a helicopter known as Extortion 17 was shot down in 2011 in Afghanistan." data-mediaviewer-credit="Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-extortion17/29seals-extortion17-articleLarge.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="401" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="600" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">The burial site at Arlington National Cemetery for the remains of the men killed when a helicopter known as Extortion 17 was shot down in 2011 in Afghanistan.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Gabriella Demczuk for The New York Times        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="425" data-total-count="21014" itemprop="articleBody">With multiple deployments over the last 13 years, few of the unit’s members are unscathed. About three dozen operators and support personnel have died on combat missions, according to a former senior team member. They include 15 Gold Squadron members and two bomb specialists who were killed in 2011 when a helicopter with the call sign Extortion 17 was shot down in Afghanistan, the most devastating day in Team 6 history.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="322" data-total-count="21336" itemprop="articleBody">Blasts from explosions used to breach compounds on raids, repeated assaults and the battering from riding on high-speed assault boats in sea rescues or training have taken a toll. Some men have sustained <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/subjects/v/veterans/traumatic_brain_injury/index.html?inline=nyt-classifier" title="More articles about traumatic brain injuries." class="meta-classifier">traumatic brain injuries</a>. “Your body is trashed,” said one recently retired operator. “Your brain is trashed.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="451" data-total-count="21787" itemprop="articleBody">“SEALs are a lot like N.F.L. guys: They never want to say ‘I am taking myself out of the lineup,’” said Dr. John Hart, medical science director at the Center for BrainHealth at the University of Texas at Dallas, which has treated many SEAL patients. “If they send guys back in who already have the effects of a concussion, they are constantly adding a dose of a hit to an existing brain condition. The brain needs sufficient time to heal.”</p><h4 id="subhead-3" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="16" data-total-count="21803" itemprop="articleBody">Latitude to Kill</h4><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="505" data-total-count="22308" itemprop="articleBody">Early on in the Afghan war, SEAL Team 6 was assigned to protect the Afghan leader Hamid Karzai; one of the Americans was grazed in the head during an assassination attempt on the future president. But in the years that followed, Mr. Karzai became a bitter critic of the United States Special Operations troops, complaining that they routinely killed civilians in raids. He viewed the activities of Team 6 and other units as a boon for Taliban recruiting and eventually tried to block night raids entirely.</p><figure id="media-100000003703922" class="media photo embedded layout-jumbo-horizontal media-100000003703922 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-protection/29seals-protection-master1050.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-protection/29seals-protection-master1050.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-protection/29seals-protection-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="SEAL Team 6 was assigned to protect the Afghan leader Hamid Karzai. After an assassination attempt in 2002 in Kandahar, a team member whose head was wounded used his shirt to stanch the bleeding." data-mediaviewer-credit="Ed Wray/Associated Press"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-protection/29seals-protection-master1050.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="688" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="1050" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">SEAL Team 6 was assigned to protect the Afghan leader Hamid Karzai. After an assassination attempt in 2002 in Kandahar, a team member whose head was wounded used his shirt to stanch the bleeding.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Ed Wray/Associated Press        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<div id="MiddleRight7" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-17">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="319" data-total-count="22627" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-17">Most missions were not lethal. Several Team 6 members said they herded women and children together and knocked men out of the way, with a push or a gun muzzle, to search homes. They frequently took prisoners; a number of detainees had broken noses after SEALs punched them in struggles to subdue them, one officer said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="535" data-total-count="23162" itemprop="articleBody">The Team 6 members often operate under the watchful eyes of their commanders — officers at overseas operations centers and at Dam Neck can routinely view live surveillance feeds of raids provided by drones high above — but are also given wide latitude. While Special Operations troops functioned under the same rules of engagement as other military personnel in Afghanistan, Team 6 members routinely performed their missions at night, making life-or-death decisions in dark rooms with few witnesses and beyond the view of a camera.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="405" data-total-count="23567" itemprop="articleBody">Operators would use weapons with suppressors to quietly kill enemies as they slept, an act that they defend as no different from dropping a bomb on an enemy barracks. “I snuck into people’s houses while they were sleeping,” Mr. Bissonnette says in his book “No Hero,” written under the pseudonym Mark Owen. “If I caught them with a gun, I killed them, just like all the guys in the command.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="529" data-total-count="24096" itemprop="articleBody">And their decisions tend to be certain. Noting that they shoot to kill, a former noncommissioned officer added that the operators fire “security rounds” into those who are down to ensure that they are dead. (In a 2011 mission on a hijacked yacht off the coast of Africa, one Team 6 member slashed a pirate with a knife and left 91 wounds, according to a medical examiner, after the man and other attackers killed four American hostages. Operators are trained “to slice and dice every major artery,” said one former SEAL.)</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="550" data-total-count="24646" itemprop="articleBody">The rules boiled down to this, the noncommissioned officer said: “If in your assessment you feel threatened, in a split second, then you’re going to kill somebody.” He described how one SEAL sniper killed three unarmed people, including a small girl, in separate episodes in Afghanistan and told his superiors that he felt they had posed a threat. Legally, that was sufficient. “But that doesn’t fly” in Team 6, the noncommissioned officer said. “You actually have to be threatened.” He added that the sniper was forced out of Team 6.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="301" data-total-count="24947" itemprop="articleBody">A half-dozen former officers and enlisted troops who were interviewed said they knew of civilian deaths caused by Team 6. Mr. Slabinski, a former senior enlisted member of SEAL Team 6, said he witnessed Team 6 members mistakenly kill civilians “probably four or five times” during his deployments.</p><figure id="media-100000003703928" class="media photo embedded layout-large-horizontal media-100000003703928 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-funeral/29seals-funeral-popup.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-funeral/29seals-funeral-popup.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-funeral/29seals-funeral-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="A funeral for Afghans killed in a joint American and Afghan raid in Ghazi Khan in Kunar Province, in December 2009." data-mediaviewer-credit="Rawa.org"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-funeral/29seals-funeral-popup.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="413" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="550" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">A funeral for Afghans killed in a joint American and Afghan raid in Ghazi Khan in Kunar Province, in December 2009.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Rawa.org        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="288" data-total-count="25235" itemprop="articleBody">Several former officers said they routinely questioned Team 6 operators when their suspicions were raised about unwarranted killings, but they usually found no clear evidence of wrongdoing. “There was no incentive to dig deep on that,” said a former senior Special Operations officer.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="144" data-total-count="25379" itemprop="articleBody">“Do I think bad things went on?” another former top officer asked. “Do I think there was more killing than should have been done? Sure.”</p><div id="MiddleRight8" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-18">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="268" data-total-count="25647" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-18">“I think the natural inclination was, if it’s a threat, kill it, and later on you realize, ‘Oh, maybe I overassessed the threat,’ ” he said. “Do I think that guys intentionally killed people that didn’t deserve it? I have a hard time believing that.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="430" data-total-count="26077" itemprop="articleBody">Civilian deaths are an inevitable part of every war but in conflicts with no clear battle lines and where enemy fighters are often indistinguishable from noncombatants, some military law experts say, the traditional rules of war have become outdated and new <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/subjects/g/geneva_conventions/index.html?inline=nyt-classifier" title="Recent and archival news about the Geneva Conventions." class="meta-classifier">Geneva Convention</a> protocols are necessary. But others bristle at the notion, saying that the longstanding, unambiguous rules of behavior should govern murky, modern combat.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="381" data-total-count="26458" itemprop="articleBody">“Emphasizing these lines and rules becomes even more important when you’re fighting a lawless, remorseless enemy,” said Geoffrey S. Corn, the former senior law of war expert for the Army’s Office of the Judge Advocate General and now a professor at South Texas College of Law. “That is when the instinct for revenge is going to be strong. And war is not about revenge.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="372" data-total-count="26830" itemprop="articleBody">Near the end of an Afghan deployment by Team 6’s Blue Squadron, which concluded in early 2008, elders complained to the British general whose forces controlled Helmand Province. He immediately called Capt. Scott Moore, commander of SEAL Team 6, saying that two elders had reported that the SEALs killed civilians in a village, according to a former Team 6 senior member.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="136" data-total-count="26966" itemprop="articleBody">Captain Moore confronted those leading the mission, which was intended to capture or kill a Taliban figure code-named Objective Pantera.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="401" data-total-count="27367" itemprop="articleBody">When Captain Moore asked what had happened, the squadron commander, Peter G. Vasely, denied that operators had killed any noncombatants. He said they had killed all the men they encountered because they all had guns, according to the former Team 6 member and a military official. Captain Vasely, who now oversees the regular SEAL teams based on the East Coast, declined to comment through a spokesman.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="238" data-total-count="27605" itemprop="articleBody">Captain Moore asked the Joint Special Operations Command to investigate the episode. About that time, the command received reports that dozens of witnesses in a village were alleging that American forces had engaged in summary executions.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="327" data-total-count="27932" itemprop="articleBody">Another former senior Team 6 member contended later that Mr. Slabinski, Blue Squadron’s command master chief, gave pre-mission guidance that every male at the target be killed. Mr. Slabinski denied that, saying there was no policy to leave all men dead. “I didn’t ever convey that to the guys,” he said in an interview.</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  comment-prompt-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-19">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="286" data-total-count="28218" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-19">He said that around the time of that raid he had been disturbed after witnessing one of the younger operators slashing at the throat of a dead Taliban fighter. “It appeared he was mutilating a body,” Mr. Slabinski said, adding that he quickly yelled, “Stop what you’re doing!”</p><aside class="marginalia comments-marginalia  selected-comment-marginalia" data-marginalia-type="sprinkled" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-20">
</aside>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="454" data-total-count="28672" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-20">The Naval Criminal Investigative Service later concluded the operator might have been cutting off gear from the dead fighter’s chest. But Team 6 leaders said they were worried that some operators were getting out of control, and the one involved in the episode was sent back to the United States. Mr. Slabinski, suspecting that his men had not been following the rules of engagement properly, gathered them for what he called a “very stern speech.”</p><div id="MiddleRight9" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-21">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="349" data-total-count="29021" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-21">“If any of you feel a need to do any retribution, you should call me,” he recalled telling them. “There’s no one that could authorize that other than me.” He said his message was intended to convey that permission would never come because such conduct was inappropriate. But he conceded that perhaps some of his men may have misunderstood.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="304" data-total-count="29325" itemprop="articleBody">JSOC cleared the squadron of any wrongdoing in the Pantera operation, according to two former Team 6 members. It is not clear how many Afghans were killed in the raid or exactly where it happened, though a former officer said he believed it was just south of Lashkar Gah, the capital of Helmand Province.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="224" data-total-count="29549" itemprop="articleBody">But the killings prompted a high-level discussion about how, in a country where many men carried guns, Team 6 could “guarantee that we’re only going after the real bad guys,” one of the former senior team leaders said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="343" data-total-count="29892" itemprop="articleBody">In other inquiries, which were usually handled by JSOC, not Navy investigators, no one faced any charges. Typically, men were sent home when concerns arose; three, for example, were sent back to Dam Neck after roughing up a detainee during an interrogation, one former officer said, as were some team members involved in questionable killings.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="335" data-total-count="30227" itemprop="articleBody">More than a year later, another mission spurred strong protests from Afghans. Just after midnight on Dec. 27, 2009, dozens of American and Afghan troops landed in helicopters several miles from the small village of Ghazi Khan in Kunar Province, and hiked to the village in darkness. By the time they left, 10 residents had been killed.</p><figure id="newsealsmap" class="interactive interactive-embedded  limit-xsmall layout-xlarge">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-22">Continue reading the main story</a>

            </figcaption>

	<!-- Artboard: 600 -->

				filter: alpha(opacity=70);
				-ms-filter:'progid:DXImageTransform.Microsoft.Alpha(Opacity=70)';
				opacity:0.7;
				color:#000000;
			}
			#g-new-SEALS-maps-600 .g-aiPstyle6 {
				font-size:14px;
				line-height:15px;
				font-weight:500;

				font-size:11px;

		</style>

<!-- Pipeline: 2015-05-25-newsealsmap | June 5, 2015, 11:16PM | ce970db5cc11d1092444b9ed5ea7015d8ace2ef1 -->
<meta name='interactivegraphic:height:300' content='974'>    </div>
    
    <div class="footer">

        
        
                <div class="interactive-credit">
            

<p class="byline-dateline"><time class="dateline" datetime="2015-06-06" itemprop="datePublished" content="2015-06-06">JUNE 6, 2015</time>
</p>
            By Joe Burgess, The New York Times        </div>
        
    </div>
</figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="451" data-total-count="30678" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-22">What happened that night is still in dispute. The purpose of the mission was to capture or kill a senior Taliban operative, but it was quickly apparent that no Taliban leaders were present at the target. The mission had been based on faulty intelligence, a problem that bedeviled United States military operations even after years in Afghanistan. A former governor of the province investigated, and accused the Americans of killing unarmed schoolboys.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="185" data-total-count="30863" itemprop="articleBody">The United Nations mission in Afghanistan issued a statement saying that an initial investigation had concluded that “eight of those killed were students enrolled in local schools.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="472" data-total-count="31335" itemprop="articleBody">American military spokesmen initially said that those who died were part of an insurgent cell that had been building improvised explosive devices. Eventually, they backed off that claim. But some American military officials still insist that all of the youths had guns and were tied to the Taliban. One NATO statement said that the people who carried out the raid were “nonmilitary in nature,” seemingly a reference to the C.I.A., which was in charge of the operation.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="211" data-total-count="31546" itemprop="articleBody">But Team 6 members had also participated in that mission. As part of the covert Omega Program, they joined an assault force that included C.I.A. paramilitary officers and Afghan troops trained by the spy agency.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="276" data-total-count="31822" itemprop="articleBody">By then, the program that had begun at the dawn of the Afghan war had changed. Forays into Pakistan were limited because it was difficult to operate there without being noticed by Pakistani soldiers and spies, so missions were mostly confined to the Afghan side of the border.</p><div id="MiddleRight10" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-23">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="233" data-total-count="32055" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-23">Over time, General McChrystal, who became the top American commander in Afghanistan, responded to Mr. Karzai’s complaints about civilian deaths by tightening the rules on night raids and scaling back the pace of special operations.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="228" data-total-count="32283" itemprop="articleBody">After years of refining techniques to sneak up on enemy compounds, Team 6 members were often required to “call out” before attacking a site, akin to a sheriff announcing through a bullhorn, “Come out with your hands up.”</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="328" data-total-count="32611" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. Slabinski said that civilian casualties occurred most often during the “call out” operations, which were meant to mitigate exactly such losses. Enemy combatants, he said, would sometimes send out family members and then shoot from behind them, or give civilians flashlights and tell them to point out American positions.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="383" data-total-count="32994" itemprop="articleBody">Mr. O’Neill, the former Team 6 member, agreed that the rules could be frustrating. “What we found was, the more latitude for collateral damage that they gave us, the more effective we were because we’re not going to take advantage of it but we know we’re not going to be second-guessed,” he said in an interview. “When there were more rules, it did get more difficult.”</p><h4 id="subhead-4" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="15" data-total-count="33009" itemprop="articleBody">Rescue Missions</h4><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="333" data-total-count="33342" itemprop="articleBody">Years ago, before the Afghan night raids and the wartime deployments, SEAL Team 6 trained constantly to rescue hostages — dangerous, difficult missions they never got a chance to perform before 2001. Since then, the unit has attempted at least 10 rescues, which have been among its most celebrated successes and bitterest failures.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="293" data-total-count="33635" itemprop="articleBody">Operators say that in rescues — considered “no-fail” missions — they have to move faster and expose themselves to greater risk than on any other type of operation so that they can protect hostages from being shot or otherwise harmed. The SEALs often end up killing most of the captors.</p><figure id="media-100000003703935" class="media photo embedded layout-jumbo-horizontal media-100000003703935 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-rescue/29seals-rescue-master1050.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-rescue/29seals-rescue-master1050.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-rescue/29seals-rescue-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Clockwise from top left: Pfc. Jessica Lynch was removed on a stretcher after being found in 2003 in Nasiriya, Iraq; the lifeboat in which Richard Phillips was held captive in 2009; the Danish hostage Poul Hagen Thisted, who was rescued in Somalia in 2012; as was his colleague Jessica Buchanan, an American." data-mediaviewer-credit="Department of Defense; US Navy; Danish Refugee Council, via Agence Frane-Presse--Getty Images"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-rescue/29seals-rescue-master1050.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="962" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="1050" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Clockwise from top left: Pfc. Jessica Lynch was removed on a stretcher after being found in 2003 in Nasiriya, Iraq; the lifeboat in which Richard Phillips was held captive in 2009; the Danish hostage Poul Hagen Thisted, who was rescued in Somalia in 2012; as was his colleague Jessica Buchanan, an American.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Department of Defense; US Navy; Danish Refugee Council, via Agence Frane-Presse--Getty Images        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="201" data-total-count="33836" itemprop="articleBody">The first high-profile rescue came in 2003, when SEAL Team 6 operators helped retrieve <a title="New York Times article" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2003/04/02/world/nation-war-prisoners-war-commandos-rescue-soldier-she-was-held-since-ambush.html">Pfc. Jessica Lynch, who had been injured, captured and held in a hospital, </a> during the early days of the Iraq war.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="580" data-total-count="34416" itemprop="articleBody">Six years later, Team 6 members jumped out of cargo planes into the Indian Ocean with their specially designed assault boats in advance of the <a title="New York Times article" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2009/04/15/world/africa/15pirates.html">mission to rescue Richard Phillips</a>, the captain of the Maersk Alabama, a container ship hijacked by Somali <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/subjects/p/piracy_at_sea/index.html?inline=nyt-classifier" title="More articles about piracy at sea." class="meta-classifier">pirates</a>. The operators, captured in a video shown by Mr. O’Neill, parachuted with swim fins strapped over their boots after releasing four boats — small, fast and equipped with stealth features to evade radar — that were each suspended by a canopy of multiple parachutes. SEAL snipers eventually killed three of the pirates.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="495" data-total-count="34911" itemprop="articleBody">In 2012, <a title="New York Times article" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/01/26/world/africa/us-raid-frees-2-hostages-from-somali-pirates.html">operators sky-dived into Somalia</a> to free an American aid worker, Jessica Buchanan, and her Danish colleague, Poul Hagen Thisted. JSOC considers its performance as the standard for such missions. The SEALs used a free-fall parachuting technique called “HAHO,” for high altitude-high opening, in which they jump from a high altitude and steer their way on the wind for many miles to cross a border secretly, an exercise so risky that over the years several men died while in training.</p><div id="MiddleRight11" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-24">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="322" data-total-count="35233" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-24">Ms. Buchanan recalled that four of the kidnappers were within 15 feet of her when the Team 6 members approached under cover of darkness. They shot and killed all nine captors while rescuing the aid workers. “Until they identified themselves, I did not believe a rescue was possible,” Ms. Buchanan said in an interview.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="361" data-total-count="35594" itemprop="articleBody">In October 2010, one Team 6 member erred during an attempt to<a title="New York Times article" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2010/10/12/world/europe/12hostage.html"> rescue Linda Norgrove</a>, a 36-year old British aid worker being held by the Taliban. Disaster struck in the first two minutes, after operators jumped from helicopters in the mountains of Kunar Province and slid down 90 feet of braided rope to a steep slope, according to two senior military officials.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="282" data-total-count="35876" itemprop="articleBody">As they sprinted in the dark toward the Taliban compound, the newest member of the team was confused, he later told investigators. His gun had jammed. “Thinking a million miles a minute,” he said, he threw a grenade at what he believed were a pair of fighters hiding in a ditch.</p><figure id="media-100000003703951" class="media photo embedded has-adjacency layout-large-horizontal media-100000003703951" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-norgrove/29seals-norgrove-articleLarge.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-norgrove/29seals-norgrove-articleLarge.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-norgrove/29seals-norgrove-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Linda Norgrove, a British aid worker, died during a rescue attempt by SEALs in Kunar Province, Afghanistan." data-mediaviewer-credit=""  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-norgrove/29seals-norgrove-articleLarge.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="365" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="600" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Linda Norgrove, a British aid worker, died during a rescue attempt by SEALs in Kunar Province, Afghanistan.</span>
                    </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="496" data-total-count="36372" itemprop="articleBody">But after an exchange of gunfire that killed several Taliban captors, the SEALs found the hostage — wearing dark clothing and a head scarf — dead in the ditch. Initially, the operator who threw the grenade and another unit member reported that Ms. Norgrove was killed by an explosive suicide vest. That story quickly fell apart. Surveillance video shows that she died almost instantly from fragmentation wounds to her head and back caused by the grenade blast, the investigative report noted.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="235" data-total-count="36607" itemprop="articleBody">A joint inquiry by the American and British governments concluded that the operator who had thrown the grenade had violated procedures for hostage rescues. He was forced out of Team 6, although permitted to remain in another SEAL unit.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="479" data-total-count="37086" itemprop="articleBody">A rescue operation two years later succeeded in releasing <a title="New York Times article" href="http://www.nytimes.com/2012/12/10/world/asia/american-doctor-dilip-joseph-rescued-in-afghanistan.html">an American physician</a>, though at great cost. One night in December 2012, a group of Team 6 operators wearing night-vision goggles burst into a compound in Afghanistan where Taliban militants were holding Dr. Dilip Joseph, who had been working with an aid organization. The first operator to enter was felled by a shot to the head, and the other Americans responded with brutal efficiency, killing all five of the captors.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="416" data-total-count="37502" itemprop="articleBody">But Dr. Joseph and military officials offer sharply different accounts of how the raid unfolded. The physician said in an interview that a 19-year-old named Wallakah was the sole kidnapper to survive the initial assault. He had been subdued by the SEAL operators and sat on the ground, hands around his knees, his head down, the doctor remembered. Wallakah, he believed, was the one who had shot the Team 6 operator.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="280" data-total-count="37782" itemprop="articleBody">Minutes later, while waiting to board a helicopter to freedom, Dr. Joseph said, one of his SEAL rescuers guided him back into the house, where he saw in the moonlight that Wallakah was lying in a pool of blood, dead. “I remember those things as clear as day,” the doctor said.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="383" data-total-count="38165" itemprop="articleBody">Military officials, speaking only on background about the classified operation, contended that all of the captors were quickly killed after the SEAL team entered and Wallakah had never been taken prisoner. They also said that Dr. Joseph had seemed disoriented at the time and never re-entered the house, and questioned whether he could have seen what was happening on the dark night.</p><figure class="promo media video embedded layout-jumbo-horizontal "
    data-videoid="100000003704113" data-media-action="inline" data-share-options-url="" data-autoplay="false" data-embedded="true"  data-adsensitivity="" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-25">Continue reading the main story</a>
    <span class="visually-hidden">Video</span>


    
    <figcaption class="caption">
        <h4 class="headline">Dilip Joseph’s Rescue</h4>

                <div class="caption-video">
        
            <div class="summary-credit">
                <p class="summary">Dr. Dilip Joseph describes the night he was rescued by SEAL Team 6 after being kidnapped in 2012 by the Taliban in Afghanistan. His account is disputed by military officials.</p>
                <span class="credit video-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
                    By Leslye Davis on                                                                <span class="visually-hidden">Publish Date </span>June 4, 2015.
                                    </span>
                <span class="credit photo-credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
                                    </span>
                            </div>

                    <div class="sharetools-video-container">
                <div id="sharetools-video-tools-100000003704113"
                    class="sharetools sharetools-video-tools">
                    <ul>
                        <li class="sharetool embed-sharetool">
                            <a href="javascript:;" data-share="embed" data-modal-title="">
                                <i class="icon sprite-icon"></i>
                                <span class="sharetool-text ">embed</span>
                            </a>
                        </li>
                    </ul>
                </div>
                <div id="sharetools-video-inline-100000003704113"
                    class="sharetools sharetools-video-inline"
                    data-shares="facebook|,twitter|"
                    data-url="http://www.nytimes.com/video/embedded/us/100000003704113/dilip-josephs-rescue.html?action=click&amp;contentCollection=us&amp;module=embedded&amp;region=caption&amp;pgtype=article"
                    data-title="Dilip Joseph’s Rescue"
                    data-description="Dr. Dilip Joseph describes the night he was rescued by SEAL Team 6 after being kidnapped in 2012 by the Taliban in Afghanistan. His account is disputed by military officials."
                    data-content-type="video">
                </div>
            </div>
        </div>
            </figcaption>
</figure>
<div id="MiddleRight12" class="ad ad-placeholder nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-25">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div>
    	<div id="MiddleRightN" class="ad text-ad middle-right-ad nocontent robots-nocontent"><div class="accessibility-ad-header visually-hidden">
    <p>Advertisement</p>
</div>
<a class="visually-hidden skip-to-text-link" href="#story-continues-25">Continue reading the main story</a>
</div><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="208" data-total-count="38373" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-25">Two years later, Dr. Joseph remains grateful for his rescue and the sacrifice made by <a href="http://atwar.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/12/10/navy-seal-team-member-dies-saving-kidnapped-doctor/">Petty Officer Nicolas D. Checque</a>, the team member killed on the mission. But he still wonders what happened with Wallakah.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="117" data-total-count="38490" itemprop="articleBody">“It took me weeks to come to terms with the efficiency of the rescue,” Dr. Joseph said. “It was so surgical.”</p><h4 id="subhead-5" class="story-subheading story-content" data-para-count="21" data-total-count="38511" itemprop="articleBody">A Global Spying Force</h4><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="387" data-total-count="38898" itemprop="articleBody">From a string of firebases along the Afghan border, Team 6 regularly sent Afghan locals into the tribal areas of Pakistan to collect intelligence. The team transformed the large, brightly painted “jingle” trucks popular in the region into mobile spying stations, hiding sophisticated eavesdropping equipment in the back of the trucks and using Pashtuns to drive them over the border.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="447" data-total-count="39345" itemprop="articleBody">Outside the mountains of Pakistan, the team also ventured into the country’s southwest desert, including the volatile Baluchistan region. One mission nearly ended in disaster when militants fired a rocket-propelled grenade from a doorway, causing the roof of their compound to collapse and a Team 6 sniper atop it to fall through onto a small group of fighters. A fellow American sniper nearby quickly killed them, one former operator recounted.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="383" data-total-count="39728" itemprop="articleBody">Beyond Afghanistan and Pakistan, members of Team 6’s Black Squadron were scattered around the world on spying missions. Originally Team 6’s sniper unit, Black Squadron was reconfigured after the Sept. 11 attacks to conduct “advance force operations,” military jargon for intelligence gathering and other clandestine activities in preparation for a Special Operations mission.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="368" data-total-count="40096" itemprop="articleBody">It was a particularly popular concept at the Pentagon under former Defense Secretary Donald H. Rumsfeld. By the middle of last decade, General McChrystal had designated Team 6 to take on an expanded role in global intelligence-gathering missions, and Black Squadron operatives deployed to American embassies from sub-Saharan Africa to Latin America to the Middle East.</p><figure id="media-100000003703962" class="media photo embedded layout-jumbo-horizontal media-100000003703962 ratio-tall" data-media-action="modal" itemprop="associatedMedia" itemscope itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-sealsbw2/29seals-sealsbw2-master1050.jpg" itemtype="http://schema.org/ImageObject" aria-label="media" role="group">
    <span class="visually-hidden">Photo</span>
    <div class="image">
            <img src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-sealsbw2/29seals-sealsbw2-master1050.jpg" alt="" class="media-viewer-candidate" data-mediaviewer-src="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-sealsbw2/29seals-sealsbw2-superJumbo.jpg" data-mediaviewer-caption="Navy SEAL training exercises carried out in Coronado, Calif., include rapid descents from helicopters." data-mediaviewer-credit="Stephanie Freid-Perenchio"  itemprop="url" itemid="http://static01.nyt.com/images/2015/05/29/world/29seals-sealsbw2/29seals-sealsbw2-master1050.jpg"/>
            <meta itemprop="height" content="696" />
            <meta itemprop="width" content="1050" />
    </div>
        <figcaption class="caption" itemprop="caption description">
                <span class="caption-text">Navy SEAL training exercises carried out in Coronado, Calif., include rapid descents from helicopters.</span>
                        <span class="credit" itemprop="copyrightHolder">
            <span class="visually-hidden">Credit</span>
            Stephanie Freid-Perenchio        </span>
            </figcaption>
    </figure>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="449" data-total-count="40545" itemprop="articleBody">SEAL Team 6 used diplomatic pouches, the regular shipments of classified documents and other material to American diplomatic posts, to get weapons to Black Squadron operators stationed overseas, said a former member. In Afghanistan, Black Squadron operators wore tribal dress and sneaked into villages to plant cameras and listening devices and interview residents in the days or weeks before night raids, according to several former Team 6 members.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="479" data-total-count="41024" itemprop="articleBody">The unit sets up front companies to provide cover for Black Squadron operators in the Middle East, and runs floating spying stations disguised as commercial boats off the coasts of Somalia and Yemen. Black Squadron members, working from the American Embassy in Sana, the Yemeni capital, were central to the hunt for Anwar al-Awlaki, the radical cleric and American citizen who had become affiliated with Al Qaeda in the Arabian Peninsula. He was killed in 2011 by a C.I.A. drone.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="291" data-total-count="41315" itemprop="articleBody">One former member of Black Squadron said that in Somalia and Yemen, operators were not allowed to pull the trigger unless the highest-value targets were in their sights. “Outside Iraq and Afghanistan we were not throwing any nets,” the former member said. “It was totally different.”</p><button class="button comments-button  theme-speech-bubble" data-skip-to-para-id="story-continues-26">
</button>
<p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="476" data-total-count="41791" itemprop="articleBody" id="story-continues-26">Black Squadron has something the rest of SEAL Team 6 does not: female operatives. Women in the Navy are admitted to Black Squadron and sent overseas to gather intelligence, usually working in embassies with male counterparts. One former SEAL Team 6 officer said that male and female members of Black Squadron would often work together in pairs. It is called “profile softening,” making the couple appear less suspicious to hostile intelligence services or militant groups.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="449" data-total-count="42240" itemprop="articleBody">Black Squadron now has more than 100 members, its growth coinciding with the expansion of perceived threats around the world. It also reflects the shift among American policy makers. Anxious about using shadow warriors in the years after the 1993 “Black Hawk Down” debacle in Mogadishu, Somalia, government officials today are willing to send units like SEAL Team 6 to conflicts, whether the United States chooses to acknowledge its role or not.</p><p class="story-body-text story-content" data-para-count="136" data-total-count="42376" itemprop="articleBody">“When I was in, we were always chasing wars,” said Mr. Zinke, the congressman and former Team 6 member. “These guys found them.”</p>
        
                                        <footer class="story-footer story-content">
    <div class="story-meta">
        

<p class="byline-dateline"><span class="byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"  itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/mark_mazzetti/index.html">By <a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/m/mark_mazzetti/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by MARK MAZZETTI"><span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="MARK MAZZETTI" itemprop="name">Mark Mazzetti</span></a>, </span><span class="byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"  itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/k/nicholas_kulish/index.html"><a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/k/nicholas_kulish/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by NICHOLAS KULISH"><span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="NICHOLAS KULISH" itemprop="name" data-twitter-handle="nkulish">Nicholas Kulish</span></a>, </span><span class="byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"  itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/d/christopher_drew/index.html"><a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/d/christopher_drew/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by CHRISTOPHER DREW"><span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="CHRISTOPHER DREW" itemprop="name">Christopher Drew</span></a>, </span><span class="byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person"  itemid="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/k/serge_f_kovaleski/index.html"><a href="http://topics.nytimes.com/top/reference/timestopics/people/k/serge_f_kovaleski/index.html" rel="author" title="More Articles by SERGE F. KOVALESKI"><span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="SERGE F. KOVALESKI" itemprop="name" data-twitter-handle="sergenyt">Serge F. Kovaleski</span></a>, </span><span class="byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person" ><span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="SEAN D. NAYLOR" itemprop="name">Sean D. Naylor</span> and </span><span class="byline" itemprop="author creator" itemscope itemtype="http://schema.org/Person" ><span class="byline-author" data-byline-name="JOHN ISMAY" itemprop="name">John Ismay</span></span></p>
        <div class="story-notes"><p>Matthew Rosenberg and Richard A. Oppel Jr. contributed reporting. Research was contributed by Kitty Bennett, Alain Delaquérière, Susan Campbell Beachy and William M. Arkin.</p></div>
